LORING VS. NEW ENGLAND

REASONS FOR JUDGMENT.

THE COURT:

In this action, assuming, without deciding, that the proceedings have been terminated in favour of the Plaintiff, I am of the opinion that the action fails because it has not been shown there was not reasonable and probably cause for instituting criminal proceedings.

The condition of Fitzgerald's mind on the morning of the arrest was, I think, this. He had been in the employ of the Mission Company for about two years - he entered that employ sometime early in 1911. He was an old resident of Lytton and up to the time of construction of the railway, there was no butcher shop in that town. The construction of the Canadian Northern being started, or reaching the vicinity of the town, a butcher shop was opened and butchering, presumably to a large extent, went on.

From the time Fitzgerald entered the employ of the Mission Company in 1911 until April 1912, none of their cattle disappeared. The butcher shop was being conducted throughout that period. About that time, April 1912, the Plaintiff purchased the butcher shop. During the summer of 1912, from April to November, no less than 16 or 17 head of Mission Cattle disappeared, and it is to be noted, all these cattle were fit for butchering.
The Mission people were not engaged in the cattle business, they merely kept a small herd, 34 head of animals or thereabouts. Just sufficient for their supply, and possibly for that of their Industrial School.

Loring being an old resident to Fitzgerald's knowledge Fitzgerald had reasonable cause to believe that Loring knew the Mission people were not in the cattle business, and consequently it would be somewhat unusual if they had sold cattle to anyone. Fitzgerald also knew and had reasonable cause to believe that Loring knew, that the Mission cattle, ranging as they did between the Fraser River and the Thompson close to the junction thereof could scarcely stray to the extent of half of the head in 6 or 7 months, so far as to absolutely disappear. Fitzgerald also knew he had requested Loring some month or two before this occurrence, to report any strays belonging to the Mission that he might come across in his travels as a cattle dealer. He further had heard from two Indians on separate occasions, detailed accounts of alleged cattle stealing on the part of Loring.

Now in that condition of things, he comes into the town of Lytton, finds in Loring's butcher corral one of the Mission cattle - that is in a place where he had reasonable cause to believe the animal was for the purpose of being slaughtered. It is to be noted this corral is not in the town of Lytton, but on the extreme edge of the town, and not in a place where cattle would be likely to be observed sufficiently to be identified. In fact it is probably only on account of the Mission people using brass or metal tags that Fitzgerald observed this particular cow in Loring's corral; and it is further to be noted that even if the Plaintiff's corral was so close to town that any person could observe cattle in it, it would not follow by any means that anyone would suspect, if they saw strange brands, that the cattle were stolen, because butchers in the upper country, or anywhere, buy cattle from
numerous persons and the cattle in the corral consequently bear many brands.

Under all these circumstances I think Fitzgerald had reasonable and probable cause for laying the Information, but it is to be remembered the onus is on the Plaintiff to show he had not. Then Fitzgerald says he went and laid the matter before the policeman at Lytton, not for the purpose of having criminal proceedings taken, but in order that the policeman might come down and authorize him to take the cow out of the corral, he thinking he had no right to do that on his own initiative. It was the policeman apparently who first suggested criminal proceedings, and Fitzgerald being an ex-policeman himself sat down and wrote out the Information. He then went to the Magistrate in Lytton, who was an old resident there, and who is not a cattle man as shown by the evidence. He was for a long time road superintendent, and is now apparently living in retirement. He laid before this Magistrate, Mr. Stevenson, all the facts and the Magistrate took such a serious view that he said it was a case for a warrant. Mr. Stevenson, the Magistrate, being an old resident of Lytton, must have known Loring was a farmer living in that vicinity, and must have known, presumably, that Loring was at that time in town, or would be very shortly, inasmuch as he had been conducting a butcher business there for some 6 or 8 months previous. That in itself is, I think, a fair test of whether there was reasonable and probable cause for Fitzgerald taking the action he did.

I am not at all sure that Fitzgerald could not escape liability if there was not reasonable and probable cause, on the ground that he laid all the facts before the Magistrate and the Magistrate directed a warrant should issue. It is true the evidence is not as clear on that point as it might be, but
I think a fair inference is that the facts were laid before the Magistrate and on the Magistrate's direction these proceedings were taken.

However, I rest my judgment on the proposition that the onus on the Plaintiff to show there was not reasonable and probable cause for laying this information has not been satisfied. And I further think there was no evidence of malice. The suggestion that a dispute between the parties over a race taking place two or three years ago engendered such malice as to cause Fitzgerald to have a sinister motive in laying this information, to my mind is not established. I think this case on that point is weaker than the case recently decided in the Court of Appeal - I think it is Prentiss vs. Anderson Logging Company 16 B.C. Reports.

The action is dismissed with costs; and as I do not decide the primary point as to whether proceedings were terminated by what occurred, I also direct that the costs in the chamber application before me in that connection be costs in the cause and therefore under this judgment recoverable by Defendant.
North Lytton, B. C.
June 22nd, 1915

A. Megraw Esq.,
Inspector

Dear Sir,

Your letter to hand re. partnership with Mr. Graham for which I thank you.

I cannot see why Mr. Dawson should be trying to make the public believe that Mr. Graham is in partnership with us. Mr. Graham is just a personal friend --nothing more, and has never been in partnership with us, either on the ranch, saw-mill or in freighting contracts.

It appears that Mr. Dawson knows more of our affairs than we do ourselves. If he would look after his own affairs as he does other people's it would be far better for the welfare of the Indians.

Yours truly,

Loring Bros.
per A. F. L.
"EVIDENCE"
Evidence taken at Lytton, June 23rd, 1915, in investigation of charges preferred by Mr. Leonard Dawson, Principal of St. Georges Industrial School, against H. Graham, Indian Agent, and others.

MR. DAWSON -- The loss of hay referred to through want of irrigation was on Lot 47 and refers to the second crop of hay and clover generally grown each year on Lot 47. Witness could not tell what was the average crop of hay grown on this lot for three years prior to 1914, and appealed to Mr. Fitzgerald who said 116 loads would be about the average first crop on that land for the years 1911-12-13 & 14. No definite amount was stated for the second crop, but both Dawson and Fitzgerald said that the second crop in 1914 was less than the second crop in former years. The loads were not weighed but Mr. Fitzgerald was sure they went considerably over a ton. The loss on potatoes was not on Lot 47 but on the home lot or school farm. There were 7 acres of potatoes in 1913 and 9 acres in 1914. A proper crop of potatoes for the 9 acres would be 80 tons and in 1914 they only got 30 tons. Shortage of water was an annual occurrence and there was interference with the water in 1912 and 1913 as well as in 1914. The fruit trees which suffered from want of water comprised peach, plum, apple and cherry. Mr. Dawson did not know the number but Mr. Fitzgerald said: 60 peach trees, 50 plum and he did not remember the number of apple and cherry trees. All the peach trees died except 3; there were 50 odd trees died in all. The ground was cultivated around the trees. They were planted in 1912. Mr. Dawson stated the market price of hay to be $30.00 to $40.00 per ton; Mr. Fitzgerald said the average price was $15.00; Mr. Dawson said they delivered it in town for $24.00 per ton and got $19.00.
per ton on the ground. The price of potatoes was $20.00 per ton which was the least price obtained by the school. The fruit trees cost on an average 35¢ each. The school held no record for Lot 47 but had the oldest record on Botannie Creek. Witness made application in June 1914 for a record from Botannie Creek for Lot 47, said record being both to divert and to store. This application was refused by Mr. Young on October 8th, 1914 and was granted by him in part on November 11th, 1914. One benefit already obtained from this application so far as right to use Botannie Creek water on Lot 47 is concerned, is the permission given by Mr. Young, Water Comptroller, to use the water up to June 15. The partial grant of this application is obtained in Mr. Young's letter in the following words:

"The application in so far as taking and using is concerned will for the present stand."

The permission to use water on Lot 47 from the Botannie ditch was given verbally and witness had no documentary evidence to establish it. The New England Company bought their holdings in 1901 from a man named Seward and the estate they bought comprised the land and improvements thereon and the water records. It was not until the Water Board investigated the record holdings in that vicinity that exception was taken to the right of the school to use the water from their Botannie ditch on Lot 47 and no objection had been made by the neighbors for first watering. Seward's clearing on Lot 47 contained about 60 acres and the school have since cleared 15 acres more. The grievance of the school in the matter of being denied the right to join in the storage scheme in connection with the Botannie Creek dam dates from a meeting held in the Hotel Lytton at which there were present, Loring, McKay, Indian Agent and Mr.
Fitzgerald who represented the School, while Loring was represented by Mr. Lucas, Mr. McKay by Mr. Murphy and Mr. Cochrane represented the Indians. They all agreed to appoint an engineer to survey the site of the dam. Christie & Dawson of Kamloops were chosen, the expense to be borne equally and the result to be reported. Mr. McKay said that the dam wouldn't hold enough for all. Subsequently to this meeting Mr. Graham invited me to his office to meet Mr. Cochrane with reference to the dam. In my report of 1914 I mentioned a serious state of affairs with reference to water and in reply I received a letter from the Department No 446, 303 dated June 16, 1914 (Letter marked Exhibit "A"). Then I made the application suggested in that letter and it was turned down as I have before said on October 8th, when I became convinced that Mr. Young had become biased against me. After first agreeing to go in together I was advised by Mr. Young through my lawyers, Messrs. Tupper, Kitto & Wrightman, that the others were going on with the scheme for storage in Botannie dam and I was to be left out. The letter was dated Sept. 23, 1914 and the last paragraph stated:

"In respect of the application of your client I will write you in a few days. The history of the situation in Lytton in respect of your client is that there has been for a number of years a series of contentions more or less bitter, and in view of this state I will have to consider granting a licence to those who have already applied for storage independent of your client, possibly refusing him."

My complaint against Indian Agent Graham in this matter of storage is that as Agent he did not look after the interests of the school which he should not have allowed to be left out, and he should not have hindered as I believe he did. There were four parties interested in the storage at Botannie Lake. Mr. McKay had the first right to store water.
in Botannie dam and built an old dam which had rotted down over ten years ago. Swan-Benson, contractors, offered to put a dam in that would cost $10000.00 and would have been there for all of us after they got through, but Mr. Drummond who was Agent at the time wouldn't give them permission. When the first meeting was held to store water the only record to store was held by Mr. McKay and it specified Botannie Lake.

I told Mr. Young that he had been influenced to keep the school out and he did not deny it. I said so to Mr. Graham in his office and he did not say anything. The reason I have for saying that Mr. Graham has an interest in Loring's farm is that he works there. He worked there last Sunday. He worked there Whitmonday. He called down one of the Lorings for feeding his horse at the haystack and said "we can sell all the hay." (Witness refused to give the name of the one who told him that he heard Mr. Graham make that remark)

A young fellow named Blanchford was fined by a magistrate for supplying liquor to Indians. He subsequently sold an animal to Mr. Graham to pay the fine and that cow now has the Loring brand upon it. It was Mr. Fitzgerald who told me that Blanchford sold the cow to Mr. Graham and Fitzgerald told me that the cow no has Loring's brand. Mr. Graham pays for things used at Loring's by his own cheque. I do not know this but I was told so; Mr. Fitzgerald told me so. Mr. Graham has an interest in teams working on the government road. I know this because he asked me for work for his teams at the time Lorings were hauling some logs for me. I know Mr. Graham has an interest in the saw-mill with Lorings because he acknowledged to the timber inspector that he had. The timber inspector's name I think is Gamble. Mr. Fitzgerald told me. I know that Mr. Graham employed Mr. Cochrane to oppose the school records because Mr. Cochrane said in court "I object
Mr. Dawson

to those two records of 1864 and 1867. The school has a record on the springs dated 1902 and it covers three springs, one on government land, one on reserve No. 21 and one on the line between Nos. 2 and 22. The proof that Mr. Graham is trying to take away our domestic water from the springs will be found in his letter to Mr. Young and Mr. Young's reply to the same. (exhibits "B" and "C") It was on April 6th Mr. Graham held a meeting at which Witness, Fitzgerald, Chief Paul McCarty, Charlie Spintium and Pete were present. It was agreed that the school was to have one spring and Spintium the other, and Spintium was to extend his ditch up to the spring. It was the same date Mr. Graham wrote to Mr. Young. The reason I say Lorings steal our water is that Mr. Fitzgerald in the presence of another party heard Mr. Loring say that he meant to interfere with the ditch by meddling with the gate and turning the water into the creek and I had to place a man at the head of the ditch to camp there to protect ourselves. They also tapped by a ditch above the house. This stealing of the water extended up to about 12 months ago. The cattle stealing was over a definite period between April and November 1912. One of the stolen cattle was found in the slaughterhouse here. The skins that they were selling at that time, many had the brand burnt out. I did not see these, but Goldberg who bought the skins did. This matter of the cattle stealing was adjudicated upon in 1912 and 1913. The first hearing was before the magistrate in Lytton. That case was dismissed but Mr. Fitzgerald was bound over to prosecute at the assizes. The next hearing was an action instituted by Loring against Mr. Dawson for malicious prosecution which took place in Vancouver before Mr. Justice Murphy and terminated in my favour. The assize case was heard at Clinton before Mr.
Mr. Dawson

Justice Gregory when the case against Loring for cattle stealing resulted in a verdict of "not guilty". The fourth hearing was before Chief Justice Hunter who disposed of the case by giving judgment for the defendant and said that he believed Dawson and Fitzgerald and did not believe Loring. I said in the public prints what I thought of Mr. Justice Gregory's decision. Subsequent to the prosecution of Loring for cattle stealing there was no more cattle stealing done in the neighborhood.

I say that Mr. Graham helped to keep the school out of the joint storage scheme on Botannie dam by not sticking up for us.

MR. GRAHAM—The loss mentioned by Mr. Dawson in his complaint to the Department is fictitious as regards him being prevented from using water to which he had any right, for he mentions a loss of hay on Lot 47 and he had no right to use water on Lot 47. If there was any loss on the home lot it was due to him using the water on land he had no record for. I think the figure mentioned of 116 loads of hay for the first crop is about right. His claim of loss of 50 tons of potatoes on the home ranch does not agree with what he told me for I heard him say last year that he had 80 tons of potatoes and all grown on the home ranch. I think if they had kept the water running on the home ranch where they had a right to use it they would not have lost so many of the fruit trees. The principal loss sustained by the school from insufficient irrigation is due to their own defective ditch which is excessively long and goes through soil which permits great loss from seepage. At the time Mr. Young turned the water off the ditch there was a loss of 47 miners' inches from seepage. Some of the loss in fruit trees also was due to bad care of the trees. Those given them free by the government were choked out with alfalfa in addition to being deprived of the amount of water they should have had. The prices mentioned by Mr. Dawson are also excessive. For potatoes $15.00 to $17.00 per ton is a good average price and $20.00 per ton for hay is higher than the average price.

The decision given by the Water Board confirmed the New England Company in first right to water in Botanie Creek but confined its use to lots 11 and 12 and reduced the amount. Mr. Young made careful examination of the water situation; I don't know whether he had been sent
Mr. Graham

for on that occasion. I know of no instance in which I sought to poison anyone's mind. I think Mr. Young, the Water Comptroller, a fair and capable man and not to be influenced by anyone beyond what he believes to be his duty. This is not merely my own opinion, but I have heard nothing but the most favourable comment on the Water Comptroller's work and that of the Water Board. I deny that I ever worked against the school, and I have done a great deal for it and helped Mr. Dawson out in every way I could, consistent with my duty. I have put myself out to obtain pupils for him. Mr. Dawson reported me to Ottawa for not getting pupils. I told Mr. Dawson where they were to be had and advised the Department to that effect and was told by the Department that I had done right in notifying Mr. Dawson where his pupils were to be found, and after that it was for him to get them himself.

As far as the storing of water in Botannie dam is concerned I tried to get an arrangement for all four. We held a meeting in the Lytton Hotel re storage of this water. At that meeting Mr. McKay said that he didn't believe the dam would hold enough for all four claimants, and he didn't think he could work with Mr. Dawson. He said that nobody could work with Mr. Dawson and Mr. Loring got up and said the same thing. Mr. McKay said that he was perfectly willing to go in with Mr. McKay and the Indians, and then Mr. Cochrane advised me that when Mr. McKay who had the storage right, held those views, I had better fall in with the other two.

I did not employ Mr. Cochrane, as Mr. Dawson states. It was the Department who employed him and I think it was a wise appointment and the Indians have got full benefit from it. In Mr. Cochrane's work before the Water Board he
clashed with Mr. Dawson. To a certain extent the interests of the Indians and the school were opposed. The first thing Mr. Cochrane opposed in behalf of the Indians as against the school was the school record on Botannic Creek. His ground of objection was that they had more land under cultivation than their record would warrant. The Indian record was only fourth and for that reason he should oppose giving so much to the school, when they were using more than their record would call for. They were remonstrated with because of this excessive use of water and there was argument on it before the Water Board. It is not true that I tried to take away water from the school for domestic purposes. In the matter of the springs on the Indian reserve the interests of the Indians and of the school were clashed and in that case I considered that my duty lay with the Indians. I don't think it would injure the Indians to allow Mr. Dawson to have water from the springs for domestic purposes and where the school could be benefited without injury to the Indians I was always willing to do what I could to meet Mr. Dawson half way to that purpose and I did so. The spring is on the Indian reserve and the water belongs to the Indians, but I know that the school needs the water for domestic purposes and under those conditions I was and am willing to divide up with the school. I have had clashes with Mr. Dawson on various things, but on most matters of business we are able to hit it off. I have found him very obstinate and unreasonable in the matter of water. I don't think he has shown a disposition to meet the Indians fairly in the matter of water, especially with the springs and the dam. I have not had much difficulty with him as regards the creek. I had
Mr. Graham

never heard of Indian Agent Irwin and the Indians allotting

and I had it after, but I did not let it take any of my time. There was no one in partnership with me; I had it myself, and after I became Indian Agent I had a manager who was Jimmy Innes. I don't think the Lorings are the criminals Mr. Dawson represents them to be. They are not South Mexican half-breeds as he has stated. Mr. Loring was an American and had served with the U.S. army in Mexican war and was a pensioner of that country. Mrs. Loring was born in Victoria, B.C. The community generally do not share Mr. Dawson's estimate of them. I am a personal friend of the Lorings. I go up there any spare time, and as I am not of a lazy disposition I work with them, but I never received wages for it, nor have I any interest with them in the ranch whatever. I have not known of any particular disagreement between Lorings and the Indians. The dislike of the Indians to Lorings is directed against one member of the family who had a butcher shop in Lytton and they blamed him for taking cattle that they lost and in that way tried to incriminate me in the charges they made against me. I think it is false what Mr. Dawson said in his evidence about Loring having skins in his possession with the brands burnt out. The credit taken by Mr. Dawson of having been the originator of the scheme for damming Botannic Lake is groundless. It was mooted many years before he came to the district, and I myself tried to get the different parties interested in it to get together 8 years ago to put in the dam. I think it was back in 1876 that Mr. McKay got his record to store water in Botannic Lake. In order to get the Indians into the scheme for damming I had to fall in with whoever built the dam, and both McKay and Loring absolutely refused to have Mr
Mr. Graham

Dawson in it; and as the Indians had a record to put water into Botannic Lake from Skoonka Creek, I couldn't let the opportunity for storing to pass and so I fell in with the other two parties, for I claim that to the Indians I owe my first duty. I believe in helping the school wherever an opportunity offers and the interests of the Indians are not injured thereby. I am of the belief that there are instances where the interests of the Indians and of the school are opposed and other instances where they are identical. There was not the disagreement in Ditcham's time which there has been since Mr. Dawson came and I believe that Mr. Dawson is in a large measure responsible for the clashing.

Mr. Dawson has never had a friendly feeling to me ever since I was appointed. He even wrote articles against me in an English magazine which he was not justified in writing for he didn't. The allegations in the article were actionable and if I had been a free agent I would have taken action against him as I was advised to do. I am not the only one Mr. Dawson cannot get along with. I think he could count all the friends he has in town on the fingers of one hand.

Sir,- I beg to report that on June 23rd I held an investigation at Lytton into the complaint of Mr. Leonard Dawson, Principal of St. George's Industrial School, and beg to report thereon as follows:

Mr. Dawson claims a loss of $2000.00 and specifies that the loss was incurred from 40 tons of hay, 50 tons of potatoes and from destruction of fruit trees. In his evidence he states that the loss in hay was on the second crop on Lot 47, for which land the New England Company have no water record and never had, although they have always used water on it from their Botannée Creek ditch and were able to gather a second crop each year at the expense of other holders of water rights below them—Messrs Loring and McKay, and even to the loss of their own school farm which was made to suffer from lack of water owing the amount used on Lot 47 in the effort to obtain a second crop. But when the Water Commission sat in Lytton at which meeting all claimants and users of water from the various streams of the district, or water precinct as it is called, had to prove their legal title to the water which they claimed, the New England Company were unable to establish any right to water from Botannée Creek for Lot 47, but they were able to show that they had the first two records (dated 1804
and 1867) from Botannie Creek for their school farm to which it had to be conveyed through a ditch some six miles long. These facts are amply brought out in the evidence taken by me and in letters from Water Comptroller, William Young, and solicitor A. O. Cochrane, (Exhibits "N" and "P").

Fortunately for the New England Company large powers are given to the Water Comptroller and in this case Mr. Young has used them generously in giving to the New England Company permission to use water from their Botannie ditch on Lot 47 notwithstanding the fact that they have been adjudged by the Water Board to have no legal right to the same. In view of these facts it will be seen that Mr. Dawson's claim of loss of hay for a second crop on Lot 47 is not sustained.

Turning to the claim of loss from potatoes there is a conflict of evidence between Mr. Dawson and Indian Agent Graham. Mr. Dawson says that he should have had 60 tons from 9 acres and only had 30 tons, showing a loss of 30 tons. Mr. Graham was sure that Mr. Dawson had told him that he had saved a crop of 80 tons of potatoes from nine acres of the school farm in 1914. Later Mr. Graham found an old notebook which he had used in 1914 and an entry in it made about the end of 1914 bears out the correctness of Mr. Graham's contention during the hearing. The entry is found in Exhibit "M". In a measure also this entry is corroborative in part of Mr. Dawson's own evidence for it shows him to have been right in saying that a proper crop would have been 80 tons, only he appears to have forgotten that the school had gathered that much in 1914 and that he had told Mr. Graham so. I must therefore come to the conclusion that the alleged potato loss was not sustained.

With no legitimate loss on the hay and no loss on the potatoes the balance would have to be made up on the fruit
trees. Taking Mr. Fitzgerald's count at "50 odd" trees that died and allowing it to be 55 trees at $25 each the loss would be $19.25 instead of $2000.00. But Mr. Graham claims that neglect of the trees which were allowed to be choked out with alfalfa contributed to the fatality.

Mr. Dawson's statement as to the amount to which the Water Board cut down the New England records need not be discussed as the Indian Agent seems to be in no way responsible for it nor connected with it, and the Department of Indian Affairs are not likely to be interested in any disagreement between the Principal of St. Georges School and the Water Comptroller. The reason for the reduction in quantity so far as the Comptroller is concerned, is set forth in his letter marked Exhibit "M".

The principal grievance of St. Georges Industrial School is in not being allowed to participate in the building of the storage dam on Potanum Lake. That the fact of being thus barred from participating in that project means a more or less serious material loss, there can be no question. The point to be determined is why they were barred and who is responsible for it. Mr. Dawson says the Indian Agent is responsible and Mr. Graham and others say Mr. Dawson is. Much evidence was taken on that point, but the weight of it evidently favours Mr. Graham's contention. A careful examination of the evidence will show that those who wanted to keep Mr. Dawson out (and it was Messrs. Loring and McKay who wanted to do so) had two good reasons for it. The one was that the school having no storage right but merely a diversion right, were in no position to contribute any legal strength to the partnership; and the other and main reason was that Mr. Dawson had managed to make himself personally objectionable to these two men by his tendency to quarrel with them, for in the assertion of his own rights—both real and assumed—he had no misgivings about riding roughshod.
over the rights of others. Why I regard this the main reason is that there was another reason why they should have wanted to have had him in with them on it, and that was to share up the expense with them. But when they were ready to forego that very obvious advantage, it shows how strong their personal antipathy to Mr. Dawson had become.

Mr. Dawson is too much given to jumping at conclusions, and because Mr. Graham managed to get the Indians into the storage scheme while St. Georges Industrial School was cut, he at once assumed that Mr. Graham was the cause of his being kept out, or at all events could have carried the school in with him if he had wanted to do so. But as there were those two reasons for keeping Mr. Dawson out, so there were also some reasons for taking the Indians in. These were that the Indians could contribute some legal strength and substance to the enterprise by holding a storage right on Shoona Creek whose waters could be diverted into Botannie Lake; moreover they (the Indians) were not personally objectionable to Messrs Loring and McKay who had always neighbored with them on satisfactory terms, and one of whom (McKay) held the first storage right on Botannie Lake. Besides, they could contribute their share of expense and labour in the building of the dam, which they did. Under these circumstances I am satisfied that Mr. Graham, acting on the advice of Mr. Cochrane, solicitor for the Indians, was not only justified in entering into arrangements to have the Indians included in the storage scheme, no matter whether the school was to be taken in or left out, but he would have been guilty of bad management and serious neglect to the Indians if he had failed to get them in.

To make plainer this matter of the benefit to be derived from possession of the Indians' storage right on Shoona Creek, some knowledge of the topography of the locality is necessary.
The Fraser valley in which St. Georges Industrial School is located, at this point runs approximately north and south, and the Thompson empties in from the east at a point about two miles below and south of St. Georges. Botannie Creek flows into the Thompson from the north, thus paralleling the Fraser from which it is separated by a high range of hills terminating southward at the Thompson River, the three streams forming the three sides of a quadrilateral. The drainage basin of Botannie Creek is very short—not more than about 16 or 17 miles. Botannie Creek does not flow out of Botannie Lake, but seems to rise some distance south of it. Skoonka Creek does not drain into Botannie Lake but flows past the north end of it in a southeasterly direction towards the Thompson into which it empties a few miles farther up than the point at which Botannie Creek empties. By diverting the water from Skoonka Creek a short distance up, it can be made to discharge into Botannie Lake basin. This has been done and the dam on Botannie Lake is now full. Mr. Dawson should see that when the Indians have this storage water right on Skoonka, this should be sufficient reason for the Indians being taken in. I cannot see therefore that the point against the Indian Agent is well taken on Mr. Dawson's part and it has not been established.

Mr. Dawson's complaint that the Water Comptroller had been poisoned against him by the Indian Agent is one which does not appear to be capable of satisfactory proof either for or against. Mr. Dawson bases his proof on his own statement that he had charged each and neither had denied. Both Mr. Young and Mr. Graham regard the charge as too preposterous to be discussed, and probably this reluctance to discuss was what Mr. Dawson interpreted as failure to deny. Before dismissing that feature of the complaint I may say that I have had good opportunity to note how generally satisfactory Mr. Young's work is regarded over the province. He is one of the few men who could safely be trusted.
with the large power given him under the present Water Act, for he does not appear to be influenced by any personal likes or dislikes, and I fail to see wherein he has shown any disposition to show prejudice to Mr. Dawson or the New England Company.

Turning to the charge that Mr. Graham "actually employed lawyer Cochrane to oppose his records" this is disproven by Mr. Graham's evidence taken in conjunction with the statement of Mr. Cochrane (Exhibit "F") and Mr. Dawson had no evidence in support of it except his own statement.

The matter of right to the springs does not appear to be clear. The letter of Mr. Young, Water Comptroller, makes it evident that there is some right on springs held by the New England Company under a record dated 1902, and such right is claimed by Mr. Dawson in his evidence (page 5). The description of the springs in application made by the New England Company for their record of 1902 is shown in Exhibit "G". Mr. Graham brought out in evidence (pages 10 & 11) that a re-survey was ordered by the Water Board and had been made. A plan of this survey will be seen in part of Exhibit "G", obtained from Water Rights Branch of the Lands Department at Victoria. Nevertheless these springs are claimed for the Indians by the Department of Indian Affairs as will be seen on page 53 of the Schedule of Indian Reserves for Reserves No. 21 & 22. Mr. Graham's contention is that the record of 1902 claimed by the New England Company is not good insomuch as it was obtained by a wrong description in the application, which tended to mislead the resident Water Commissioner who issued it, and in this contention he seems to be borne out by the statement of the Water Comptroller (Exhibit "H") where he says:

"The Water Board has no authority to grant a record to the New England Company for water off any of the Reserves."
The additional claim to the water from the springs on the reserve which Mr. Dawson sought to establish in his reference to Mr. Irwin, does not seem to be borne out in the letter from Mr. Irwin, (Exhibit "Q"). Even if it were so that Mr. Irwin had done as claimed by Mr. Dawson, that could have no bearing on the case so far as present right is concerned, for Mr. Irwin had no power to grant water belonging to the Indians to any other person.

The next phase in connection with Mr. Dawson's complaint about the springs is that Mr. Graham was trying to deprive him of the use of domestic water from the springs. In view of the conversations which passed between them, as shown in the evidence and also the letters, it is rather remarkable that Mr. Dawson should make this charge against the Agent. Apart from Mr. Dawson's assertion to that effect there does not seem to be anything to bear it out. On the contrary it seems to be pretty well established from the evidence that Mr. Graham recognized the need of the school for domestic water from the Indian springs and was always willing to facilitate matters in that direction. Exhibits "D" and "E" appear to show very conclusively that there was no contumacy or wanton opposition on Mr. Graham's part, but rather a desire to concede as much as he possibly could without injury to the Indians. It is very true that he remonstrated against the Indian Spintum being deprived of water from the springs both for domestic purposes and for irrigation. Why his doing so should be characterized by Mr. Dawson as a "specious plea" does not appear clear. The evidence of Fitzgerald and Smith and also their sworn depositions put in by Mr. Dawson and to be found as "I" and "J" of the Exhibits to refute the claim that any of the Indians had been deprived of domestic water, will be seen at the bottom of page 14 of the evidence to refer only
to the time "since Spintum put that little ditch up the hill" and in his letter to the Water Comptroller (Exhibit "H") Mr. Graham specifies "last season." Thus this part of the evidence of Smith and Fitzgerald was given to disprove an alleged statement by Mr. Graham which Mr. Dawson fancied had been made but had not been made nor intended by Mr. Graham, although the Water Comptroller appears to have rather carelessly transcribed it that way.

Next, Mr. Dawson makes the charge that "Mr. Graham is mixed up in so many outside businesses which clash with his duties as Indian Agent and prevent him acting fairly to this school and the Indians generally." This is the same charge made in the complaint of the Indians against Mr. Graham, investigated by me on May 8th, 1915, and reported on to the Deputy Superintendent General, but in the investigation the Indians repudiated having included it in the charges made by them. It was also made by Mr. Dawson in a letter to me under date of May 10th, 1915, a copy of which I forwarded with the report above mentioned, and from that circumstance I inferred that Mr. Dawson was either responsible for, or in some way connected with, the formulation of the Indians' charges. Now that it is again repeated by Mr. Dawson there is no longer reason to doubt the origin of a part, at least, of the Indians' charges. It is therefore up to Mr. Dawson to make good what the Indians refused to endorse. He charges that Mr. Graham is financially interested with Lorings in their ranch; in a saw-mill, and in freight teams. His reason for charging Mr. Graham with having an interest in the Loring ranch is that Mr. Graham had been seen at work on it, and also that he had been heard to make a remark which tended to the supposition that he was interested in the ranch; but it is still only supposition and he refused to say who had heard the remark. All the evidence
Mr. Dawson had to offer on this will be found on page 4 of his deposition and on pages 12 and 13 of his cross-examination by Mr. Graham. In view of the unsatisfactory hearsay character of Mr. Dawson's evidence on these points and Mr. Graham's flat denial supported by data such as he furnishes in his own evidence and in Exhibits "E" which is capable of being verified with files in the Department, I am of the belief that Mr. Dawson's charges in this connection are not only unproven but are in a great measure disproved.

The charges which Mr. Dawson makes against Loring's of stealing water and stealing cattle belonging to the school is, so far as the cattle are concerned, a revival of civil and criminal cases adjudicated upon in the courts of this province and somewhat fully set forth on pages 5 and 6 of Mr. Dawson's evidence and in Exhibits "S", "T" and "U". It will be noted that in his charge against Loring's Mr. Dawson says: "have for years done their best to hurt us by stealing our cattle and water" which implies that cattle and water are still being stolen from him, but in his evidence he corrects this and restricts the cattle stealing to a definite period in 1912 but still ignores the fact that two Courts of this Province had already decided that Lorings had not been guilty of cattle-stealing at all and that the other two did not adjudicate upon the charge of cattle-stealing at all but on that of malicious prosecution which is altogether the text of Justice Murphy's decision (Exhibit "U"). The Lorings, so far as I can learn, bear a good reputation in the community, and in view of the adjudication of some years ago I do not think Mr. Dawson was justified in making the charge again in the manner in which he did. As for stealing of the water, I have reason to believe from what has transpired that the Water Comptroller and his engineers who have thoroughly looked into the matter, regard Mr. Dawson as the more blameworthy of the two for the disagreements which have taken place.
The last three paragraphs of Mr. Dawson's complaint seem to put in more definite form his grievance against Mr. Graham in connection with the exclusion of the school from participation in the building of the storage dam at Botanie Lake. But as I have already gone into that pretty fully there is no need to repeat the points brought out and the conclusions I drew from those points. It is very unfortunate that the school has been left out, but I cannot see that the Agent is in any degree responsible for it. It has been pretty plainly shown from the evidence that Mr. Dawson is responsible, and I am quite sure that the Water Comptroller is of the same belief as myself in that connection. If not, I do not understand what he means in that last paragraph of his letter (Exhibit "N") where he says:

"I see no reason why the Industrial School should not eventually have storage privileges with the other users, but it will rest with the authorities of the school."

By it he evidently means that with another man than Mr. Dawson in charge, the school could have obtained and might still obtain storage privileges with the others, in Botanie Lake, and I think the Water Comptroller has good grounds for arriving at that conclusion.

If Mr. Dawson's appointment as Principal of St Georges Industrial School rested with the Department of Indian Affairs I would feel it my duty to recommend that he be asked for his resignation, as a means to restore harmony in that Agency. He has prejudiced the interests of the School in being the direct cause of exclusion from the storage project and I am convinced that he has considerable to do with dissatisfaction among the Indians against the Agent, although I doubt whether he is as much to blame in that connection as his employee, Fitzgerald, who seems to work under-handedly among the Indians, carries carries tales to Mr. Dawson and has a faculty for keeping him in hot water.
That Mr. Dawson's heart is in his work and that he has succeeded in building up the school and secured an attendance far over that of his predecessor there can be no question, but I have reason to believe that much of that success in getting pupils is due to the assistance he had from the Indian Agent, while his predecessor, from what I can learn, had practically no assistance from the Agent who preceded Mr. Graham. Neither was it generous on Mr. Dawson's part to say of his predecessor: (page 23 of the evidence) "When I came there were only five boys in the school and the Indians were not welcome inside the gate." The first part of that assertion may be true, but I doubt the second part. It does not comport with the general impression entertained of his predecessor, Mr. Ditcham, who appears to have been able to get along agreeably with others, and it is very much like so many other conclusions arrived at by Mr. Dawson on altogether insufficient foundation and with too great tendency to believe the worst rather than the best. Mr. Dawson, I believe, means to do well, and his morbid disposition and tendency to quarrel is his misfortune rather than his fault.

There are some other features of the situation to which I might refer but they have no direct bearing upon the things charged by Mr. Dawson which I was instructed to investigate.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Inspector of Indian Agencies

Memorandum,

Mr. Scott.

I have carefully read over Mr Megraw's report of his investigation into the complaints preferred by Mr. Leonard Dawson, Principal of the St George's Industrial School, against Indian Agent Graham at Lytton, B.C.

Although Mr Megraw has not made any definite recommendations, still, his opinion is very clearly stated. He entirely exonerates Mr Graham and shows that some of the complaints should never have been made and that others are the result of Mr Dawson's inability to live on satisfactory terms with his neighbors.

That the School should have lost heavily through an insufficient supply of water is very regrettable, and Mr Megraw has endeavoured to place the responsibility for this loss. He has found that the blame falls more upon Mr Dawson himself than upon Mr Graham, and points out that the School has no legal right to storage of water, and that that was the main reason why Mr Dawson was not allowed to join with the others in the
construction of the storage dam. Both Mr Megraw and Mr Young are of the opinion that had a reasonable man been Principal of the School, he would have been allowed to share in the expense and benefit.

I do not find any of the complaints against Mr Graham justified, and although Mr Dawson, in a letter dated June 26th, complains about Mr Megraw's unfair investigation; Mr Megraw, on his part, stated on June 25, that his task was not rendered very agreeable and implies that the fault lay, not with Mr Graham, but with Mr. Dawson.

Perhaps the clearest statement in Mr Megraw's report is in the last paragraphs, when he remarks that if Mr Dawson's appointment rested with this Department, he would feel it his duty to recommend that Mr Dawson's resignation be called for as a means of restoring harmony in the Agency.

The evidence, which is voluminous, entirely bears out Mr Megraw's report, and it seems a pity that an Indian Agent should be placed upon the defensive by Mr Dawson, who thinks that even the Commissioner of Water Rights and Supreme Court Judges are biased because they are willing to become active partisans upon his behalf.

Sir,

I beg to advise you that the Rev. Leonard Dawson of St. George's School wrote to the Comptroller of Water Rights asking him to use his influence with so that I would consent to allow him, Mr. Dawson, the use of the Ditch as there is only one Indian using water at the present time and he is not using half a ditch full.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Dear Mr. Scott:

Agent Graham has written to me to see if it is possible to obtain exemption for the St. George's Industrial School at Lytton from the payment of water rentals, the same as has recently been done in the case of Indian Reserves as this school is now a Government institution and it would assist greatly if the rentals were waived from these accounts. I have it that Agent Graham informs that he should deal with the Provincial authorities on this subject, but as the Lytton Industrial School is within the Railway Belt and the Provincial Government only administers water rights within the limits of it at the school, the Dominion Government is of the opinion that the exemption of rentals is a question to be dealt with by the Ottawa authorities by way of an Order-in-Council being passed granting such exemption, and such Order then being forwarded on to the Provincial Comptroller of Water Rights for his information and guidance.

If you think my views on this point are sound I would suggest that an Order-in-Council should be passed covering the situation and have it forwarded on to the Provincial authorities so as soon as it would, Agent Graham states, assist in keeping down the expenditure at this school.

As to the status of the land at this School I am not sure, but I may say if the title has passed from the New England Company to the Dominion Government it should be free from taxation by the Provincial Government.

The British Columbia Water Act makes no provision for exemption of water rentals on lands owned by the Dominion, but as the Dominion owns the water within the Railway Belt it appears to me that the Ottawa Government would be perfectly within its right in exempting this Institution from payment of water rentals even if the title to the land is not held by the Dominion Government.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir:

I beg to inform you that on the 22nd of September, during my absence, Mr. Balls, the Senior Assistant Engineer of the Dominion Water Board Branch, received a notification from the Board of Investigation under the British Columbia Water Act reading as hereunder:

"Conditional Licence No. 687, Botanie Creek, appurtenant to certain lands in the vicinity of Lot 47, G.I., Kamloops Division of Yale District, has been referred to the Board of Investigation, together with correspondence from your Department relating to an application for the extension of the time within which to complete works.

"It appears that the time for completion of these works expired on the 1st of November, 1920, and that no land had then been brought under irrigation. At the present time (some 5 years later) very much the same conditions prevail and the Board is of opinion that the licence has become null and void. Consequently, it is unable to grant or recommend the granting of the extension applied for.

"I enclose herewith a formal notice to the licensee to show cause why the licence should not be cancelled for non-use.

Upon my return to the City I immediately wrote to Mr. Indian Agent Graham in an endeavour to ascertain the status of this land, as it was part of the holdings of the New England Company, and in his reply he stated that he thought that while you were in England you intended to take up with the New England Company the matter of purchase of all its land holdings.

On receipt of this information I wrote to the Board of Investigation asking them to withhold the cancellation of the Licence until I could learn from you on your return to Ottawa, whether the land which the Licence is appurtenant to was now controlled by our Department, and the Board consequently have agreed to take no further action until I can give it definite information in the matter of ownership.

This Licence, I may say, is an important one, as the water was intended to be used as far as it would go on the land described in the Licence and the remainder from the storage system from Bootanie Lake recently completed which was for the irrigation of both Lot 47 and the lands described.

Dear Mr. Scott,

Re: The Water Rights on Lot Forty Seven & adjoining acreage.

If the Water Rights branch insist on the use of the storage water in the lake, it will necessitate the expenditure of approximately $1000.00. There is no need whatever in the Dept. having to spend any amount. If the Water Rights Branch can be made to see that for the present, this water can be very profitably used for a second watering on Lot 47, with an extension of the water rights, now expiring each year on July the 15th. There is an opportunity in this second watering for immediate revenue which I need, which will, if properly handled, relieve the Dept. of perhaps extra expenditure on the School.

I have already started the men to cut some fence posts to fence Lot 47 together with about 50 acres adjoining. This latter acreage has essentially been brought in under cultivation & it is my intention to do this gradually, beginning with from four to eight acres of potatoes next spring.

To purchase the wire for this needed fencing I thought of asking the Dept. for the expenditure of $500.00 to be taken from the New England Grant for next quarter, thinking this would be the most plausible way to overcome the necessity both for myself & the Dept.

I have written Mr. Molan concerning the water & trust that he will be able, together with Commissioner Ditchburn, to arrange for the use of part of the storage water on Lot 47 in order to get a second crop, which would increase our output of hay on this Lot by about 100 tons giving us immediate revenue.

Yours very sincerely,

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

Re: Letter No.165-0-9 of Nov.24th, concerning water rights for Lot 47 & adjoining acreage. I have had some correspondence on the matter with Commissioner Ditchburn & have also written Inspector Pragnell, asking him to take the question up with the representatives of the Water Board in Kamloops.

The Conditional License No. 880 which Commissioner Ditchburn has been successful in having renewed, calls for rights on the acreage adjoining Lot 47, about fifty acres, of which has been slashed, ten acres ready for cultivation except for a small percentage of stumping which I hope to get cleaned up during the coming winter months. The remaining forty acres will take some time & work to be brought into cultivation.

When asking for the raising of the Dam at Botanic Lake I had not thought so much of the land adjoining Lot 47 as I did about Lot 47 itself. Our present Water rights on Lot 47 expire, or run out, each year, on the fifteenth of June, with a mutual agreement extending these rights to July the 15th., giving one crop only, while a much greater benefit would be derived if the storage water could be used on Lot Forty seven to get a second crop.

I would suggest that if it is at all possible arrangements should be made so that enough of this storage water should be used for a second watering on Lot 47. In fact this is the only way in can be used to derive the greatest benefit & financial help to the school.

There is storage room for 300 acre ft. of water which would easily irrigate 75 acres of land & it would be unreasonable, to say the least, if the water board would now insist upon the clearing of the above No. of acres when the land already cleared with the rights extended to cover the whole irrigating season, that is, that I be allowed to use sufficient of the storage water to irrigate Lot 47 from the 15th. of July until Sept 30th., would probably give me beginning next summer an additional 100 tons of hay to dispose of at the rate of perhaps $20.00 per ton.

I trust this will explain the matter & that you will if possible take the necessary steps to XXX enable me to get the greatest possible benefit out of the use of this water.

Yours very sincerely

Sir:-

I herewith beg to acknowledge receipt of departmental letter dated December 30, 1935, with reference to the number of children in this Agency of school age, who are not attending school, etc.

In reply thereto I beg to advise the Department that after going carefully over the census, I find there are approximately ten children, who are of school age, who are not attending any school, of whom three have just turned seven now; two are living in the Nicola Agency and two others are of doubtful health.

During the months of September and October Constable MacKay and myself visited the homes of all children not at school and in the latter month summoned several of the parents who refused to permit their children to come to school. Unfortunately during that time there was an epidemic of influenza and several cases of pneumonia at the school. One of the Smoker girls, Lillian, whose father was summoned, being in an undernourished condition, contracted pneumonia and died. The hue and cry raised caused me to cease recruiting until the termination of this epidemic, as the Indians claimed that their children were being taken to the school, only to die.

It so happened that during the time of Inspector Barry's visit this epidemic had about run its course at the school, although there were still a number of influenza cases from the school still in hospital, besides one scarlet fever case from the local rancherie. Shortly after the Inspector's visit an epidemic of measles broke out, starting at the Foster Bar School twenty-two miles up the Lytton-Lillooet Road, and several of the Indian children of that vicinity, two of whom attended that school, were afflicted. Subsequently it reached St. George's Indian Residential School when a large number of the children, together with several of the school staff came down with it, and are still on the sick list.

After the death of Lillian Smoker, Dr. Ellis advised that no more children be brought into the school until the influenza epidemic had ceased, but now the school is under full quarantine owing to measles, and has been from the first week in December, when the trouble first broke out at the Foster Bar School.

On the receipt of the above mentioned letter from the Department, I again approached the doctor regarding the recruiting of the few children in this Agency still out of school, but he would not hear of any being brought in owing to the serious consequences that might result therefrom.

Dr. Ellis this morning reported two cases of chickenpox on the local rancherie at Lytton.

In conclusion I may advise the Department that no effort

Dear Mr. Sutherland:

Answering you letter #165-0-10, dated June 16th.

Pupil No. 0135 Eileen Thom:
This girl, if she passes her grade VIII, would like to take grade IX and continue her music. She comes from Lytton and has an opportunity of assisting in the Church and community.

Pupil No. 0155 Mary Dick:
This girl's mother is dead and her father has married again. Because of this she feels the need of school protection and I think she should have such care for at least another year. She is not a bright youngster but is conscientious and wants to be of some use to her people.

Pupil No. 0119 Mabel Sami:
This girl has become extremely interested in her music and also wishes to take grade VIII work. Her farther is a white man, her step-father an Indian. Since she wishes to return I feel she is sincere and that the extra year would benefit her greatly.

Pupil No. 0147 Rosie Jones:
Rosie wishes to continue for the next year. While she is in her eighteenth year, or just gone seventeen, yet I feel it would be to her advantage to return.

Pupil No. 165 Minnie Albert:
This girl, while she has expressed her desire to return, would benefit by another year at school but as yet I do not think her parents will allow her to continue. The family has always given trouble but lately her parents have shown more friendliness. I have therefore asked for her return in order to give her an opportunity with her parents to make a choice for themselves.

Pupil No. 114 Nellie Bent:
This girl is in her last year of high school and
Wishes to try her Junior matric. Last Wednesday she took a final in one Subject (Chemistry II) in which she evidently did very well. Her tests so far have averaged 72%.

Pupil No. 149 Gladys Shute:
This girl has just gone sixteen and should not go out now since she is anxious to continue. Her parents are agreeable.

I have been able during this last school year to have a definite course in music given and all of these girls are anxious to continue this training. While some have done extremely well, yet lessons for eight months are insufficient to benefit greatly. With another year the older girls would be fitted to at least take care of mission church services. I have, in this training, had in mind the mission work as well as the social uplift tendency which music instills. I have picked pupils from widely separated districts so that they could be of assistance, especially in Church life.

The Department has also to remember that the school is not only an institution of Academic and technical training, there is a great deal of work entailed in cleaning, cooking and washing which smaller girls cannot readily do, therefore we need these older girls to assist in the general work and which helps to keep down expenses.

Pupil No. 239 Tommie Hall has just gone sixteen and since he wishes to return it would be wise to allow this. Pupil #295 Jimmie Dick has also just gone sixteen. He wishes to return for another year's training. This pupil is a brother of Mary Dick, the family situation also applying to him.

I trust you will see fit to allow the return of these pupils, especially as the girls would benefit greatly with their music.

Yours very obediently,

A. R. Dett,
Principal.

Dear Mr. Sutherland;

I understand, from Indian Agent Barber, that there is some objection from the Roman Catholic Church regarding six of the children lately sent into this school. In connection with which I might say that the work was entirely done through our Missioner at Shulus and in so far as the school is concerned we had nothing to do with bringing in these children. It is true I visited the parents with the Missioner, but visited them as Anglicans.

It is very evident, from the point of view of baptism, that three of these children are definitely Anglicans, the other three, being baptized by the Roman Catholic Church, have been, from their early age, recognised and taught in the Anglican faith and received in the Anglican Church; therefore all are definitely Anglicans. The parents are definite in their wishes that their children remain in St. George's and the children, themselves, are extremely happy and have very strongly expressed themselves as not wishing to return home or to be sent to another school.

I do not wish to appear a busy-body but wished to point out to you the situation and feel keenly that the children are in their right place and do not wish to lose them. It is also a case of exercising our own rights.

Yours very obediently,

A. R. Lett,
Principal.

Jimmy Major also informed me that his father, the Guardian of Mathew desires the boy to go with John to Kamloops. I, however, have not yet been able to interview Old Major personally. Mathew was baptised in the Anglican faith and is now at St. George's School.

In view of Jimmy Major's expressed desire to me, I cannot recommend his admission to St. George's School be approved. I will, however, trust that the Department will advise on this application at an early date, in order that I may advise the Church authorities.

I expect that due to the overzealousness of the new missioner, we will have more complaints of this nature in the future, as if one side trespasses, the other side is sure to retaliate.

In this regard I would advise as follows: On Sept. 14th I received from the Principal of St. George's Residential School, applications for admission of the following children, all of which were supported by certificate of the parent or Guardian, to the effect that it was their desire that their children be taken to St. George's School and brought up in the Anglican Religion.

Mary August
Hazel August
George August
Mathew McKay
John Hubert McKay
Howard Coulter Shulus (Lower Nicola)
Elizabeth Bostan Quilchena Creek (Lower Nicola)

A few days later the Roman Catholic Missioner called at this office and complained that all the above children were Catholic children (except Elizabeth Bostan, whose name was not mentioned.) and that they should go to the Kamloops School. He also produced statements of the parents: Charlie August, Mrs. Charlie Swakum, Jimmy Major and Major H. McKay, to the effect that they desired their children brought up in the Roman Catholic Religion and taken to the Kamloops school. The Roman Catholic Missioner requested me to have the children returned from St. George's School and sent to Kamloops, immediately.

In view of the above I advised both the Anglican Missioner and the Roman Catholic Missioner to submit copies of the baptism records of these children, and that I would myself interview the parents in the matter.

This I have now in several instances done, and obtained a further certificate of their desires in the matter.

I also have in several instances received copies of baptismal records, all of which I am forwarding to the Department herewith for their consideration.

I would advise that this trouble appears to have arisen through the Anglican Missionary recruiting pupils for St. George's School, on the Coldwater Reserve, which is looked upon as being totally Roman Catholic, though apparently, as will be seen by the records submitted herewith, there are some families of the Anglican faith who moved there years ago, and whose children are baptised in the Anglican faith.

Dear Sir,

The Department is in receipt of your letter of the 20th ultimo, with reference to certain applications that you have received for the admission of children to the St. George's Indian Residential School.

When there is any doubt whatever regarding the religious affiliations of any child for whose admission to a residential school application is made, all the facts should be submitted to the Department and our decision given before the child is admitted to the school.

You should not take statutory declarations from Indians regarding the religious auspices under which they wish their children educated unless you receive specific instructions from the Department to do so.

The information forwarded states that the mother of Elizabeth Alice Beaton and the father of John Hubert McKay are members of the Church of England. If you are satisfied that this information is correct, you may authorize their admission to the St. George's Residential School.

The Department has carefully reviewed the correspondence submitted with regard to the applications for the admission of Howard Coulth, Mary August, George August, Hazel August and Tillie Swakum. In each of these cases, there is definite information to show that the father is recognized as a Roman Catholic. In view of Section 10 (1) of the Indian Act, the Department is not prepared to approve the admission of these children to the St. George's Indian Residential School and, if they are at present in the school, you should at once notify the Principal to return these children to their parents. Please let me know when you have taken action in this matter.

As pointed out in the first part of this letter, when you are doubtful regarding the religious auspices under which a child should be educated, you should make full inquiries, with a view to ascertaining the religion of the father. This information should then be forwarded to the Department and we will decide in what school the child should be placed.

Yours truly,

T. R. L. MacInnes,
Acting Secretary.

Sir:

In reply to Departmental letter No.165-0-10, of the 5th instant, which is hereby acknowledged, I respectfully advise that Mary and George August, and Tillie Swakum, were not returned to their parents by Mr. Lett, Principal of St. George's Residential School, until the last December, whereas it was agreed that they, along with Howard Coutlee and Hazel August, would be returned home on December 15th. However, Howard Coutlee and Hazel were sick, and therefore some delay was caused. I believe, by waiting for these two to recover enough to travel. Howard Coutlee was returned home on the 8th instant, but Hazel August is still at the School.

On the 12th instant I visited the School to effect the transfer of Ada George to the Kamloops Residential School, also to bring Hazel August home to her parents, but found the School quarantined for measles (only two cases) and therefore could not remove the children. I had not been notified of this outbreak by Mr. Lett, who, however, is to advise me as soon as the quarantine is lifted, when I will immediately transfer Ada George to Kamloops School, and bring Hazel August home to her parents.

I attach hereto copies of two letters received from Mr. Lett, which explain the situation.

I will advise the Department as soon as these transfers have been made. I might advise that the extreme cold weather of the past ten days has prevented me from bringing the children from the School.

Dear Mr. Barber,

Regarding the children of your Agency whose admittance to St. George's School was protested by the Roman Catholic Church authorities, namely, Howard Coutlie, Mary August, George August, Hazel August and Tillie Swakum. I wish to advise that all of these children have been returned to their homes as per your instructions, except for Hazel August. This last named child will be returned immediately the quarantine on the School has been lifted.

Your letter of November 26th quoted to Department's instructions as follows:

"... In each of these cases there is definite information to show that the father is recognised as a Roman Catholic. In view of Section 10 (2) of the Indian Act, the department is not prepared to approve the admission of these children to the St. George's School..."

I wish to state that, in regard to the above, that the Department's decision is, I feel, quite fair and just, and I have so informed the parents concerned, except in the case of Tillie Swakum. At the mother's own request I now ask you to reconsider her case. According to the Department's own judgement (as quoted above) this child should be eligible for admission to the St. George's School, and I submit the following information in proof that Charles Swakum was an Anglican.

The full facts are as follows:

(A) Charles, the father of Tillie Swakum, was an Anglican during his whole lifetime, and until his death in December 1935. I visited him regularly in my priestly capacity. Knowing this, the surviving relatives brought his body to me for burial.

(B) Charles Swakum in September 1935, asked me to send his daughter, Tillie, to St. George's School to be brought up as an Anglican like himself. As the child was then under age, my reply was that he must wait until the following year, when I would make the necessary arrangements.
(C) Charles Swakum died on December 22, 1936, and his body was subsequently brought to me for burial.

(D) In August, 1936, according to the deceased father's wish, the child Tillie was sent to St. George's School, by the surviving parent.

Attached hereto are three extracts from the Shulus Mission's records which practically give a complete history of Charles Swakum's religious life, proving him to be a recognised adherent of the Anglican Church.

Your early reply will be appreciated.

Yours truly,

(Rev.) Cyril Silva-White

Missionary at Shulus.
Sir:

I respectfully forward herewith for the consideration of the Department, a letter received from Rev. Silva-White, Missioner at Shulus Indian Reserve, which is self-explanatory.

In regard to Tillie Swakum I would recommend that she be admitted to St. George's Residential School, in view of the Anglican Church records, copy of which is attached, and the fact that the mother of the girl is anxious that she be allowed to attend the St. George's School.

The complications in regard to this girl arose through the father, who apparently was an Anglican, going to live on the Coldwater Reserve, where he resided for 15 years prior to his death, and there being looked upon as a Roman Catholic in common with the whole of the Coldwater Band.

Dear Mr. Ibelan:

I have just finished my quarterly reports and you will notice that Hazel August and Ada George, both of whom appear on the discharge sheet at the end of the December quarter, and who during this quarter were unable to be moved as expected, Hazel to her home and Ada to the school at Kamloops. I trust that the Department will see fit to allow their names to stay as per capita earning pupils for this quarter.

Indian Agent Barber came yesterday for Ada and expected to take her right through to Kamloops. Hazel is still in bed and is not in a condition to be removed.

A great number of our children are still hanging fire with temperatures and cardiac. Dr. Ellis is removing a number to their homes, which fact is going to make it rather difficult for the school financially during the next two quarters.

You will find, by our discharge sheets, that we have lost six children, four of whom passed away directly due to the epidemic and we still have two girls who are not expected to return to health again, which will make eight losses in all since the first of January. You can readily see that we have had a very trying spell which the school will feel for years.

Yours very sincerely,

A. R. Lett,
Principal.

Dear Sir,

In accordance with Circular Letter No 150-37 of March 30th last, I have submitted to the Merritt and Lytton Agencies lists of the names of those children who at the Doctors request, have now been transferred to their respective homes on the reserves for rest and recuperation after the late severe epidemic.

I would be very grateful if you would remind the Agent at Lytton of the necessity of his close attention to the health of these children in their homes, mentioning also that he might materially help in having those children who are allowed home until June returned promptly. I have taken the matter up with the parents and they have promised their co-operation.

I note with satisfaction the Departments decision regarding the extension of the Summer Vacation. This will obviate more than one difficulty experienced in respect to the short six week vacation period.

I have of necessity, from a business point of view, to think in terms of Per Capita Earnings and may I ask if I shall be allowed earnings for the full roll strength of the School for the vacation months. Will those children, for example, whom the Doctor has sent home indefinitely, and whose return is expected after the vacation, and who now become non-earners, become earners at the last of July and continue to be so for the months of July and August? I would be glad of your advice regarding this. My earning capacity, as you can see, is terribly reduced and while I need all the pupilage can earn yet I do not wish to tread where I ought not to.

I have been obliged to reduce my staff and am not myself a good typist which I hope you will overlook.

Sincerely,

Dear Parents and Friends:

I am a little behind in my first letter to you, but it will have more school news for you, I hope.

First of all, may I thank those from whom I have had letters of good wishes, and God's blessing for this school year. I wish I could really make you feel as I do when I receive a letter from parents of our children, extending well wishes and blessings. I thank you from the bottom of my heart. Those letters received from parents living in that big reserve of Shuswap are very much appreciated, and especially so since so many of our children come from the Lower Nicola Valley.

The parents have not all kept their promise in having their children in on time. I had hoped that with the long holiday this year, equal to the white schools, you would be very punctual, but we had many stragglers, and even yet a number have not returned. This fact does not help out your boys or girls, nor the other children in the Grades to which the missing ones belong. It is very upsetting to the school's advance of your children. I am sure you wish the very best for your children, and one way, perhaps the greatest way, you can carry out that wish, is to see that your children return punctually and attend regularly. I am glad to say that this applies only to a few, but please let me try and impress upon that few, the retarding effect you exercise on the school on the whole. Nobody cares so much about the welfare of your children as you do yourself—and you owe your child a chance to prepare himself or herself, for after-school-age life.

There are a number of Indians who are still holding their children away from school. In cases, these children are reaching the ages of ten, eleven and twelve years. In holding back your children this way you are doing very unfair to them. The greatest gift you can give your child is education. The Department makes this very easy for you because it takes full responsibility for educational expenses, making education free to you, and surely it is your duty to avail yourself of this for your children's sake. The school needs your children in order that it might do its best for all. Please send them in, and we shall do the best we can for them.

Again we have had a medical survey of the school, and we are very happy to be able to report to you that your children have passed a really good test. There are no children suffering from Tuberculosis. The Doctor has asked permission to have diseased tonsils removed. Many of the children have tonsils which are impairing their health, and we need your consent to have this needful operation performed. Please write me, giving your permission, and I shall be able to allow the Doctor to perform such operations when convenient to him and the hospital. Your attention in this is important.
At the present time, because there is an outbreak of infantile paralysis in B.C., we are isolated. Will you be good enough to remember, that for the present you cannot visit the school. We are all in the best of health, and we are thankful to Almighty God for this blessing.

We held our largest Thanksgiving service on the 20th Sunday after Trinity, and the hospital at Lytton benefited by receipt of the chapel decorations of flowers, vegetables, and fruit, for which the Matron has expressed her grateful thanks. We hereby wish to thank the missionary at Shulus for his helpful Thanksgiving address.

The School has helped in filling the relief car, loaded at Lytton and sent to the drought-stricken areas in the Indians. The congregation has also forwarded $25.00 in cash. We are thankful that the year has brought us good crops so that we are able to help those in need.

Mrs. M. Frest, who came to us last Autumn for the first time, is with us again this year. She is widening her course of handcraft in wool, to rug-weaving. She is also teaching bead-work.

Handicraft and Manual Arts are being extended into leather work. Our music teacher, who takes vocal as well as piano, is also able to give leather work instruction. This will be done with the regular buckskin tanned leather, and will be developed to cater to tourist sales.

At this time of the year many of you will go to the mountains to hunt deer and goat. Don't kill for killing's sake. God gives us the game for our use, and you should be careful in the first place to conserve, by taking only what you need, and waste none by leaving it to decay—bring it out for winter food.

May God bless you all, and remember always, that you must fit yourself to receive the best from your Heavenly Father by obeying His Commandments, by being sober, honest and peaceful in your homes, and amongst your friends. We ask you to remember us always, in your daily worship and in your church services.

Your sincere friend,

[Signature]

The above children have not been examined for some time due to the great difficulty in visiting them because of bad weather and roads, and also the difficulty in bringing them in to see me for the same reason.
