It is difficult to understand the Principal's attitude in respect to the seven children returned home last spring with a number of other children, some of whom have returned, some who have died. The school has a full staff including the Principal, Vice Principal, Boys' Instructor or Supervisor, a Registered Nurse, and also two cars at their disposal. Yet, seemingly no effort has been made on the part of the Principal to visit these children, although a few of them live within easy distance of the school. One would expect that after the condition in which these children were sent home from the school, the Principal would at least show some interest in their welfare. As he has time for outside activities, it cannot be that he is pressed for time.

It should be remembered that this is a large, busy Agency in which I am practically alone. I feel that too much time is being taken up on groundless complaints from the Principal of the St. George's School being sent to the Commissioner's office at Vancouver as well as to the Department at Ottawa.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

A. Strang

Dear Sir:

I herewith beg to acknowledge receipt of Departmental letter 165-0-10 dated January 5th instant with reference to certain children not yet returned to the St. George's Indian Residential School.

In this connection, I beg to enclose a letter just received from Dr. Ellis reporting on the present condition of the seven of the children mentioned in your last letter. These children are the balance of those sent home last spring too sick to carry on. I may say that I have kept in close touch with these children either by visits or by communication with the parents or relatives, and as they recovered, they were sent back to school with no opportunity wasted on my part.

Regarding Johnny Green and Cecil Samson, the former was given permission to stay home to look after his grandmother's ranch during the winter months. There was no one else available at the time, as the grandfather died last spring. This boy's case was discussed by the Principal and myself. Johnny is fifteen years old, and is only passing into Grade 6. He had reached the stage where he was discontented at school, and being as slow as he is, I consider him better off doing what he is doing than attending school.

With regard to Cecil Samson, as soon as the school was out of quarantine, I had this boy brought to my office. I was away at Lillooet on Departmental duties at the time, so my clerk asked Mr. Lett, the Principal, to come for him. This he refused to do saying that the boy should have been brought in before; that he did not want him now as he would retard the whole class. When I returned the boy had gone back home with his father. The reason the Principal gives for the boy's return home is that he did not get the Doctor's examination. However, the Doctor is always available in Lytton. I now understand Mr. Lett does not want these two boys returned.

This boy had not been returned, but on receiving this report I immediately took steps to ascertain his whereabouts and found that he had been living near Lytton with his friends, these people stating that his presence with them had been reported to the Office at Lytton, but the School had no information regarding his whereabouts.

I also have your report from Mr. Coleman regarding the health of Elizabeth Bent. I might say that Mr. Coleman and Mr. Barber have both sent in their reports to me answering my queries, but up to the present time, excepting for your letter regarding the children on the Lytton agency I have had nothing. There are a number of eligible children in this agency who should be in the School at the present time and who would mean much to our financial status. I have gone to many of these parents and they have all promised me faithfully that their children will be brought into School, but they have not carried out their promises. It is therefore, I think, the Agent's business to see that these children are brought in.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

May I call your attention again to the quarterly Reports, in regard to those children who are still absent?

The Department's Medical representative has closed the School since September 22nd, against any children returning or any possible visitors coming in, owing to the fact that one of the Indian parents contracted infantile paralysis.

The Indian was sick some twelve days prior to the Doctor's knowledge and it was feared perhaps the School would fall prey to this disease.

The children are late in returning and in reality should have been in the School much before September 22nd, but unfortunately when a number of them were ready to be brought into the School, they were sent home at the Doctor's orders.

Yesterday, I had a conversation with Dr. Ellis and he hopes to lift the quarantine against those children and I expect within the next few days they will be returned to us. I shall, however, keep you posted.

May I specially point out to you that there are no cases of infantile paralysis in the School, but that the School is closed to any people who would wish to come in.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

In connection with my quarterly returns, may I call attention to Pupils Nos. 0221 and 0253 - Elizabeth Adams and Margaret Smoker - who have been truants unreturned since last October.

Inspector Barry at his last visit carefully investigated their accusations from the School standpoint and I understood from him at the time of his inspection that he expected to go on to the reserve and see the parents of these children. This fact, I am told indirectly, did not materialise owing to unsatisfactory arrangements being made to ensure the parents being at home to meet Inspector Barry.

I think you will agree with me that some report should be given the School so that I may intelligently make my returns, and I do not quite understand why these children, since their accusations against the School are absolutely unfounded, should be allowed to remain out. As you know, it is not in my jurisdiction to go on to the reserve and forcibly have these children returned, but I might say I do feel strongly that such cases should be allowed to maintain their charge against the School as it does more harm than one is aware of. I think it would be wise for the Department to enforce their return, even if they ask for their immediate discharge.

Regarding Pupil No. 0208 - Janet Peter Charlie - this girl has been discharged at the request of the Agent on application from the Chief, and Pupil No. 338 - Nelson Floyd Raphael - was discharged at my request because of his bad influence in the School, and I trust the Department will see fit to approve.

Pupil No. 0228 - Mary Mack - who was sent home after the epidemic in 1936 has not been reported to me for some time and in taking her name off the list, I feel it is being
done without proper regard for her condition of health at the present time. I have seen this girl quite often and recently and she seems to be in very good health.

Pupil No.320 - David Lewis McKay - Whilst I have no report about him I would suggest that my action in deleting his name should be maintained.

Yours very faithfully,

[Signature]

Principal.
Ottawa,
April 18, 1939.

Dear Sir:

On checking the March quarter return of the St. George's Indian residential school it is noted that Elizabeth Adams, No. 0221, and Margaret Smoker, No. 0253, truanted from the school last October and have not since returned.

As the former is stated to be 12 years of age and the latter 11 it is difficult to understand why they have not returned to school. Please make a personal investigation of the home conditions of these two children and if you find them in good health arrangements should be made for returning them to the St. George's Indian residential school immediately. Please let me know when you have taken action in this matter.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Sir:

In reference to Departmental letter No.165-0-10 dated April 18, relative to Elizabeth Adams, No.0221, and Margaret Smoker, No.0353, truant pupils from St. George's residential school, I beg to report that the former mentioned girl was returned to school recently but has since been sent to hospital and the Doctor now advises that this girl will not be again fit for school as she is suffering from a rheumatic heart condition and nephritis. I would respectfully recommend that this pupil be deleted from the school register.

Margaret Smoker, whose date of birth is September 13th, 1925, is at present, and has been for some time, looking after a sick relative who is a helpless cripple. I have endeavoured to have someone else look after the crippled woman but without success. Considering the girl's age (nearly fourteen years) and the considerable friction the girl's family has had with the school, I feel it would be advisable to have her also removed from the school register.

I have conferred with Rev. A.R. Lett, Principal of St. George's School, in regard to having these two pupils struck from the list and he is agreeable to this action. I trust the Department will favourably consider removing these pupils from the school register.

Your obedient servant,

A. Strang,

Dear Mr. Hoey,

My Secretary has been unfortunately ill in the Hospital and has just returned to the Office, and I have had to hold over my applications for discharge certificates.

In this respect, may I point out that I am expecting this year to close the School on the 20th June and it will be necessary for these certificates to be here in time for presentation at the closing exercises the evening of the 19th. We have certificates for a great number of our children issued last year in mistake and will use those now, but will need the extras, and may I ask your immediate attention, please?

Our reasons for closing early are that we may have the children returned August 20th, and thus avoid their going to the hop fields, sanction for which has been given to us under date May 26th, by Mr. Phelan.

Reverend Sir:

A review of the December quarter return of the St. George's Indian Residential School shows the following pupils over the age of 16:

No. 0118 Bessie Kelly
" 0129 Theresa Williams

No application for retaining these children in your school has been received and in this connection I wish to direct your attention to circular letter of July 21, 1939, a copy of which is enclosed.

As pointed out in the circular letter the Department realizes that frequently there are reasons for keeping certain children after they reach the age of 16 but at the same time the consent of the Superintendent General (Minister) must be obtained.

I may add that in the past the Department has been favourably disposed to allowing certain pupils, especially girls, to remain in residential schools after they reach the age of 16 if good reasons for such action are given by the Principal and approved by the Indian Agent. However, in view of the fact that the number of children of school age is apparently increasing and the further consideration that due to the conditions now confronting us there is no immediate prospect of our securing funds to provide increased pupilage at Indian residential schools, it is considered that in future it will be necessary to adhere more strictly to the provision of the Indian Act requiring discharge of pupils at 16 years of age.

Rev. A. R. Lett,
Principal,
St. George's Indian Residential School,
Lytton, B. C.
I feel you will agree with me that it is not fair to deprive children of education simply because the accommodation that might be available for them in a residential school is being used by those who have had the advantage of residential school training for some years and who have reached the age of 16 years.

Until further advised you should make arrangements for the discharge of pupils when they reach the age of 16 unless there are some very exceptional circumstances and in this event full particulars should be given to the Department and our permission obtained before such pupils reach the age of 16.

With the above in mind I desire to hear from you at the earliest possible date stating the date on which the pupils mentioned in the first part of this letter can be discharged from your school.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

File References Re: Jackie W MAJOR, Indian Boy - missing from St George's Indian School - Lytton, B.C.

Headquarters On the morning of Saturday May 4th inst., the Indian Agent at Marritt, B.C. stated that the above named was missing from the Indian School at Lytton, B.C., and requested our assistance in locating the boy.

Accordingly on the instructions of the N.C.O./o Marritt Detachment, I proceeded to Lytton per Police Transport, Code No 2542. Enquiries were instituted at Lytton and eventually MAJOR traced to a point called Gladwin, B.C. Here it was found that he had been given a lift by Indians of the Spences Bridge Reserve, and another lift later on into Marritt by Indians of the Canford Reserve.

On returning to Marritt the boy was found in company with his mother, and on her assurance to the Indian Agent that she would be responsible for him overnight, he was allowed to stay with her.

On Sunday, the fifth, the boy MAJOR was returned to the Rev H.S. Lett, Principal of St George's School at Lytton, a patrol per Police transport being made for this purpose.

Dear Sir:

Re Geoffrey Sam.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letters of June 18th and November 2nd, with reference to the admission of Geoffrey Sam, Indian boy of the Lower Nicola Band, to St. George's Indian Residential School.

This boy's parents live beside the main highway toward's Merritt, almost two miles from the village of Shulus. The distance to the Shulus School too far for him to travel alone. His father feared that he would be run over by cars if allowed to play along the highway and asked that he be admitted to St. George's School.

Apparently the Rev. Mr. Lett had him brought to the School, as application for his admission and covering letter dated June 6th 1940, was received at this office and forward to the Department by me. Your letter of June 18th was in reply to these.

Geoffrey Sam will be seven years of age on Dec. 27th next. As he has been attending school this term I would recommend that he be allowed to remain at school.

Your obedient servant,

(G.C. Mortimer)
Indian Agent.

Dear Mr. Hoey,

With reference to the graduation class this year, I would like to state with regard to pupil No. 0210, Mandy Machelle, born March 13th, 1924, that this girl has done awfully well in handicrafts and has expressed a wish to return to school next year for continued instruction.

I would like to make a recommendation that after the holidays, if she still wishes to do so, she be allowed to return. I think she would be an asset to the Department in after school life with regard to follow-up work, if she receives this additional training. Dear Sirs: Re-quarterly report of St. George's Indian Residential School, Lytton, B.C.

It gives me great pleasure to submit herewith a brief quarterly report of St. George's Indian Residential School, for the period ending, September 30, 1941.

The school re-opened for the present term on Monday August 18, and before the end of the first week a large majority of our student body were back in residence. The children appeared very happy to return to classes, and their parents expressed in general their good-will. As far as student numbers go, I feel that in the very near future St. George's School will have a waiting list for admissions.

Prior to the children's return to school, the whole of the school was thoroughly cleaned. All walls and floors were scrubbed and staff rooms kalsomined. The boys' playroom was given very careful attention, and new lockers are at present being made in our manual training room to replace the old lockers. A small reading room for Senior Boys' was fitted out with tables and chairs, and they have found this a great help to them in the evenings. The school entrance, main corridors, and staff sitting room were done over and re-arranged to give a brighter and more cheerful appearance to the school.

The cleanliness of the children has been given very special attention. All boys' wash to their waists daily. They also have a foot bath each night before retiring, and once a week all have a warm body bath under supervision. Following this bath each boy's body is examined by our school nurse, Mrs. C. Lowe. One of the Senior boys' has also been instructed in the art of hair cutting, thus each Saturday Morning any boy desiring his hair trimmed, appears at our school barber shop.

The diet of the children has been carefully planned. The weights of all children were taken on entrance to school this fall, and are to be taken each month thereafter. We are glad to find that some children have gained as much as seven pounds this month, and very few have not gained at least two pounds.

For the present (until our new principal gives his sanction) I have allowed the children only one half hour of games or gymnastics in the evening, twice a week. In the past in my estimation
this kind of recreation has been overdone, and no doubt was the indirect cause of ill health and loss of weight among these children. The majority of children here are under 13 years of age, and are up in the morning around 6 a.m. and after working out one-half day on the farm, followed by one half-day in the classroom, together with their playground exercise, can't have a great deal of surplus energy left for organized evening games. Since we have given them more rest, we find they are more eager to do good work in the classroom and on the farm.

The staff and I have done our best to bring a calmer attitude among the children here. They are extremely excitable and will need a great deal of care to bring them to an understanding of self-control. In fact the whole school in the past has been somewhat possessed by a restlessness, and I would believe it was fostered by unhappiness and the frequent changing of staff. Last year alone, ten changes were made in staff during the term and four at the end of June. This has a very harmful effect upon the school as a whole.

Day and night fire drill have been carefully carried out. I have also given the boys' a great deal of instruction on this important matter, and at last we have them reacting to the various emergencies in a calmer and more logical manner. I have also made it my business to have a nightly round made of the school at 10.30 p.m. to see there are no danger of fire breaking out.

All four of the entrance class passed their examinations to High School. One boy Clarence Walkem, (brother to Miss Edith Walkem, teacher in our intermediate Room here) is taking High School in my classroom at present. He appears bright like his sister, and should do well in the future.

The staff of the school are doing very careful and painstaking work in their various departments. In fact they all appear exceptionally happy, and the atmosphere of the school is gradually clearing. To add to the social aspect, the Head Matron has organized the following gatherings; A Red Cross Meeting for the ladies of the staff one evening per week; and one evening for them to have tea together in the staff sitting-room about 9.30 p.m., and one evening for badminton in the school gymnasium.

The religious instruction of the school has not suffered. Fifteen minutes per day is still devoted to this work, additional to daily prayers said in the chapel. Each Sunday the local Anglican Priest from Lytton attends to our Communion Service, and I am responsible for the 11 a.m. service. The Administrator of the Diocese has given me a temporary license for church duties.

May we also on this occasion take the privilege of thanking Dr. W.H. McGill, Director of Indian Affairs, and Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., for honoring us by a visit on August 21. We would also like to thank all officials in Ottawa for their kind cooperation in helping us over the difficult period of the last few months.

We would also like to express our appreciation to our local Indian Agent, Mr. A. Strang, for his untiring aid and advice to us; and to Captain G.H. Mortimer, Indian Agent, Merritt, B.C., for his assistance in collecting the children of his Agency; and lastly but not least may I thank the Department for the privilege so kindly given to me, in permitting me to carry on, in the capacity of "Acting Principal" during the
Quarterly report------continued

last quarter.

Respectfully submitted,

Acting Principal

Dear Sir:

I herewith acknowledge receipt of Departmental Letter with reference to the September Quarterly Returns of the St. George's Indian Residential School.

In respect to Lena C. Dick, whose name was shown on the June quarter return and does not appear on the September return. This girl was not a strong child and did not enter school until she was 11 years old. The child was conscious of her age and size compared with the other children in her grade; and this made her very nervous. The principal, Mr. Lett, I understand did not improve matters by quarrelling with the parents, because of having a girl of this age starting school and gave them to understand that he did not care if she continued at school or stayed at home. I was unaware of this at the time.

The father is employed on the railroad and is now working some distance outside the district, and Lena is now in her thirteenth year. Under these circumstances I would respectfully suggest that her name appear on the next quarter's Discharge List.

Your obedient Servant,

A. Strang,
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

I would recommend the discharge of the pupils whose names are as follows:

Pupil No. 0246, Elizabeth James
0283 Elizabeth Alice McDougall
0317 Loretta May Smith
0321 Lena Catherine Dick

These pupils have not returned since holidays, and I would recommend that their names be taken from the roll.

Also Pupil No. 348 Clarence Walkem, who felt that he could not stay after Mr Stewart left. Mr Stewart devoted most of his time out of classroom to this boy, and at present the boy is attending the school where Mr Stewart is now teaching, and which is quite close to the boy's home. The Walkems are in good circumstances, and can very well take care of the boy's education. I would recommend that his name be taken from the roll.

Also Pupil No. 334 Clarence Spinka and No. 420, Ronald Thomas. These two pupils find it difficult to settle down, and are old enough to be of help to their parents. Neither are a good influence in school, and we have a large number of young pupils who are quite promising if they are taken care of. I would recommend that these two pupils be discharged.

Also No. 356, Peter Marchelle, whose father is a cripple, and is quite unable to do any work around the farm or home. The boy's mother asked that he be allowed to go home and help her, and I would recommend that he be given an honorable discharge.

Dear Mr. Hives:

I have your letter of the 8th instant, in which you write in part as follows:

"Will you kindly send diplomas for pupils who will be discharged."

I am not exactly certain to which pupils you refer. You attached to your letter a list of six pupils whom you are apparently discharging at the end of June. However, from the information you supply regarding them I doubt if all of them are entitled to diplomas. In issuing these it is intended to only send them to pupils who have been in the school for a reasonable number of years and have shown decided progress in whatever work they were asked to do. Please let me know the names and register numbers of the pupils for whom you desire diplomas.

Yours truly,

Oct. 7, 1943
Lytton, B.C.

In the letter accompanying the April-June Quarterly Returns, I recommended that certain pupils should receive their discharge. This was duly sanctioned. There are several pupils such pupils who have returned, and whose parents have asked that they be allowed to continue for another term, as not being old enough to leave school. It has not usually been that way. Generally they have wanted them home as soon as possible. I would recommend that the following pupils be allowed to continue for another term:

Lily Phillips, Thelma Abbott, Mae Dunstan,
Nos. 0241, 0247, 0248 respectively.

Pupil No. 363 Earl Adams, who did not return to school after the 1942 holidays, was convicted of house-breaking with three other young men. The other young men were given term in the penitentiary. Earl Adams was committed to the Reformatory. I asked that he should be placed in my custody for a period of six months on suspended sentence. The magistrate granted my request. He is now in school, and I would recommend that he be allowed to stay as a pupil for the space of six months. He appears to be doing fairly well; and I think he will improve.

I would recommend that the following pupils receive their discharge: 388 Leonard Thomas, 404 Edward Charlie, 434 Henry Munroe, 0238 Bertha Sam, 0272 Ida Edwards. It appears that all these pupils are required at home; and I think they would be a help to their own people.

We are short of a few supplies in the classroom, and I would be very much obliged if you would supply them to us as soon as possible, as per requisition enclosed.

Chas. F. Hives
Principal.

Mr. A. Strang,
Indian Agent, LYTTON, B.C.

Oct. 14, 1944
Lytton, B.C.

Dear Mr Phelan:

I have sent in the Quarterly returns, and feel very dissatisfied with them. It has been so difficult to get the pupils back this year. The people here are quite spoilt anyway; but this year, they have had such opportunities of making money, one way or another. And they have made use of their children, even little ones, by letting them pick hops or fruit; they seem to have lost sight of the importance of education. Or at least, the school is a very secondary consideration.

We have received quite a number of new pupils. So far, I have been unable to get them all examined by the doctor; who appears to be extremely busy. I will send in their Application forms at the first opportunity. In the meantime, will you kindly allow them in as pupils. The people are all scattered over the country picking fruit, and it is difficult getting their signature to the Application forms.

I was hoping that some of the older girls would come back to work on my staff as probationers or assistants; but they found such an abundance of work with good pay awaiting them, they have not come back. I don't know what they will all do when we get back to normal conditions.

We have had great difficulty keeping a full staff; but we are managing somehow, and will continue to do so until better times come.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]
Principal.

Mr Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division,

Ottawa.
Ottawa,
October 24, 1944.

Dear Mr. Hives:

I have your letter of the 14th instant, with reference to the September quarter return of the St. George's Residential School. As soon as the applications for the new pupils are received they should be forwarded to this office. I have arranged to have the cheque for the grant go forward immediately. This cheque will include not only the regular per capita grant for the quarter but also the quarterly payment of the special grant of $15 per pupil which the Department is allowing this year.

In connection with the quarterly return I would refer you to my letter of July 12, in which you were requested to correct certain numbers shown on the quarterly return. These corrections have not been made and it would be appreciated if you would give the matter your immediate attention. This will involve giving different numbers to the new pupils who entered the school for the first time during the September quarter. I might also add that the total number of pupils shown under the heading "Class" does not agree with the total of the boys and girls. In other words, the grade of several pupils is not shown. It would be appreciated if these matters could be adjusted on the next return.

Yours truly,

Rev. C.F. Hives,
Principal,
St. George's Indian Residential School,
Lyton, B.C.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Dear Mr Phelan:

I was very glad indeed to receive your letter in answer to my request for an advance on the quarterly Grant; for it gives me the urge to write you, and try and explain to you some of the difficulties that contribute toward the problem of meeting expenses without going into debt. I must confess there are times when I feel almost persuaded to write, asking the Department to please relieve me of this job; for certainly it is a very worrying one.

The matter of lack of pupils is a very serious one. This can be accounted for in various ways. These people, from what I can see, have little or no appreciation of the value of education. At present they make such good wages without it, they don't see why they should bother to send their children to school. Our older boys during the Summer holidays were making five and six dollars a day. In fact, some who went to the States, made as much as eight dollars a day. Why should they come here to study and work for nothing? The older girls also made wonderful wages; some of them more than I can earn. And so I had great difficulty persuading them to return to school; and when a boy runs away from school, we receive no help from the parents in having him returned.

I would be very grateful indeed if you would write to the Indian Agents at Lytton, Merritt, and Kamloops, asking them to make every effort in have all school-age children in school. I feel sure there must be many of school age in the Merritt Agency who are not attending school. We did not receive one girl from there when school opened at the Fall term. We have had to send several of the Merritt Agency children to the Coqualeetza Hospital. One of them died two years ago. It is very difficult explaining to the Indians, when a T.B. clinic is held, and the X-ray reveals the workings of the T.B. germ, that it was not placed there by St. George's School. I am sure this may seem rather childish to you; but I have heard more than once that children develop T.B. as soon as they arrive at St. George's School. During the three and a half years that I have been here, two pupils have died; one at the Coqualeetza Hospital, and one at the Lytton Hospital. Many
of their own children, at home, have died during that time, but these two seem to be the only ones they remember having died.

Then there is the foolish and expensive system of outside married staff, adopted years ago. There are five cottages with married couples (three with families) living in them. This institution cannot afford this expense. Those cottagers have to be provided with fuel, light, vegetables, fruit, milk and meat rations. Their salaries have to be in keeping with their status as married people with families. The Farmer and Manual Training Instructor, each receives $90.00 per month. The Dairyman, Engineer and Irrigator each $80.00 per month. The salaries of the inside staff have all had to be raised considerably; although I have cut down their number, and I have been teaching in the Sr. Boys' classroom since the beginning of the Fall term. Yesterday I was able to engage a young man teacher, who has been discharged from the R.C.A.F. Medical Service. He receives $80.00 per month.

The B.C. Department of Education seems to be over emphasizing the matter of teachers' salaries just at present. They will find, I think, that character building does not always accompany the teacher who draws a big salary. I was greatly relieved when the Public School Inspector, during his recent inspection, said that this would probably be his last inspection of us. He has not been very helpful. His one song is about Academic training. And he criticises our methods; our equipment; religious instruction, and our salaries; and shows very plainly that he does not comprehend the nature of our work. He thinks there should be more man servants and maid servants, so that the girls and boys could go to class full time. We really send all but a very few to school full time.

Then there is the medical situation. Too many children are laid off from school and work for insignificant ailments. We not only make babies of them, but give the parents the impression that their children become weaklings when they come to St. George's School. A week or two ago, we read in the paper that Vancouver had an epidemic of measles. Although Vancouver is 171 miles away, the doctor immediately gave orders that our pupils were not to go to Lytton, and their parents were not to visit the school. I wrote to all the parents and explained as well as I could; but, at the same time, such stuff gives our school a "black eye", so that the people look upon us as a kind of a chronic pest house.

You will think I have a fit of complaints. Well, if I have, it has been on the go for a long time, and I don't think I can stand it much longer. I thought perhaps I could have climbed on the top of it before now; but somehow I did not get off to a very good start. The Church or diocese did
not welcome me. That fool of a fellow, Captain Mortimer, who was Indian Agent at Kerritt, told the people there I certainly was not his choice. Which is quite true, but he might have been truthful in telling the truth.

Some of this may appear to you to be small. It does to me also; but the truth is that it totals up to why the road is difficult. Maybe after the war, we shall be able to secure good, reliable, Christian workers who are not altogether in it for the sake of the dollar; but have as their chief objective the welfare of the Indian girls and boys. And also, maybe, when the Indians again settle down to having a hard time making a living, they will appreciate the school that cares for and educates their children.

But in spite of it all, I am not ashamed of what we have given to the work during the last three and a half years. And I rather think, if you paid us a visit, you would be somewhat proud of our children, as you see them in school.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Principal.

Dear Mr Phelan:

I have today received your letter of the 25th inst. relative to prospective pupils from the Kamloops Indian Agency. After receiving Mr Indian Agent Taylor's letter informing me of four prospective pupils of the Ashcroft Agnd, I asked one of our missionaries Rev. J. Phelps to try and locate them during one of his visits there. After his return he informed me that two of the names were unknown, and the other two were across the river some distance in the mountains; and very difficult of access without proper packhorse equipment. I have written Mr Taylor regarding all this information.

The work here has taken up most of my waking hours; and I have had to work early and late in order to accomplish what must be done in the springtime. I have had to take on the Sr. Boys classroom most of the term. Tomorrow I have a young man coming from the University of B.C. to receive me of the teaching. My Farm Manager took sick with jaundice just when the most important part of the year began. I have done every bit of plowing on the place, and finished it yesterday. This had to be done, and meant working early and late. But it is all done, and I have also kept up the Sr. Boys' classroom regularly.

During the month I have taken in five new pupils. I really think the Indians are feeling much more kindly toward the school; and appreciate the work we are doing.

I hope the labour situation will improve in the near future. I don't think it can get very much worse.

Yours faithfully,

June 6, 1945

Dear Sir:

The following names and numbers are of pupils who have been allowed to stay home for the purpose of helping their parents. The discharge of these pupils has not been recommended, for the reason they were not quite of age to leave school; and in talking the matter over with the parents, they seemed anxious that the school should have an oversight of the conduct of these pupils, in case they did not get along very well. I would now recommend their discharge. The numbers are as follows:

Nos. 383, 386, 403, 0243, 0248, 0261, 0329.

Regarding pupils numbered 433, 440, 446, and 450. These pupils are at the Coqualeetza Hospital. I believe they are improving in health; and it is only a matter of time when they will be discharged from there to return here to school. I would recommend that their names remain on the roll for the time being.

Pupils Nos. 0312, 0313, 0360, 0361 are four sisters, whose father thought he could look after them, and let them attend day school near to where he was working. About three months ago the mill, where he was working, closed down, and he brought back the girls to school. Their attendance will show on the present Quarterly Returns.

Pupil No. 424 is attending a day school, and appears to be doing very well. I would recommend his discharge from the roll of our school.

For some reason I cannot explain, pupil No. 0332, Rona Thelma Thomas has been left off the Returns since 1943; although she has been in residence continuously since that time. Her name will appear again in the present Quarterly Returns. It is to be regretted that this mistake has been made, for we can ill afford to lose the grant.

Yours faithfully,

A. Strang,
Indian Agent, Lytton.

Oct. 14, 1945
Lytton, B. C.

Dear Sir:

In sending in the Quarterly Returns for the quarter ending Sept. 30, I would explain that our attendance is down on account of having had an epidemic of measles. Many of our pupils did not come in on time, and I was therefore unable to record full attendance. And although the classrooms were open, over seventy of our pupils had measles, and could not attend classes. I am thankful to report that we are now clear of measles, and our pupils will soon all be back.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

I enclose for your approval Applications for the admission of the following named children to the Alberni Indian Residential School.

Rosabelle Douse, Kitwancool, age 14. I wish to recommend this girl for higher education as she has done splendid work and completed the seventh grade. She particularly excels in drawing and her work in this respect is most commendable.

Lloyd Milton, Kitwancool, aged 8. The parents of this boy have not lived together for several years and the mother, with whom he stayed has been in Hospital since November last suffering from tuberculosis and cancer. I would recommend that this case be given favourable consideration.

Olive Russell, Kitegukla, age 9. Owing to the father of this child working in a lumber camp too far away from the nearest Day School this child has attended school very irregularly and I feel that it would be to her advantage if she could enter the Residential School, which I would recommend.

Rita Pearl Campbell, Hazelton, age 12. The only parent living is the father of this child whose occupation keeps him away from the Reserve, in consequence of which this girl stays with different relatives and attends school very irregularly. I recommend her admission to Alberni.

Rose Rita Turner, Hazelton, age 13.

Riley Elijah Turner, Hazelton, age 10. The parents of these children suffer from tuberculosis, although the father appears to be recovering from the disease. If
their physical condition will permit I would recommend that they be kept away from their parents and enter the Alberni School.

Lawrence Percy Brown, Hazelton, age 14. Due to the death of the boy's father last year the mother has had to move around finding work and is finding it difficult to keep the boy in regular attendance at the Day School. I recommend his admission to Alberni.

Ravina Louisa Smith, Kitwancool, age 10. The mother of this girl is often employed where it is impossible to send Ravina to school. I would recommend the girl's admission to Alberni.

Samuel Evan Derrick, Kitwanga, age 10. The parents of this child are not living together and the father has a difficult time finding someone to care for the boy as his employment keeps him away from the Reserve. I recommend this boy's admission to a Residential School.

S. Mallinson,
Indian Agent

encl.
Ottawa, August 8, 1945.

Mr. S. Mallinson, Indian Agent,
Hazelton, B.C.

With reference to your letter of the first instant, the Department approves the admission of the following children to the Alberni Residential School:

Rosabelle Douse,
Lloyd Milton,
Olive Russell,
Rita Pearl Campbell,
Rose Rita Turner,
Riley Elijah Turner,
Lawrence Percy Brown,
Ravina Louisa Smith,
Samuel Evan Derrick.

Approval is granted on the understanding that the Principal can provide accommodation for them within the number for which grant is allowed. Before sending the children to the school, you should communicate with the Principal and ascertain if he is willing to accept them. Possibly he might be able to accept some but not all. In that event you may choose those who, you consider, are most deserving of institutional care.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C.,

I have been in correspondence with Indian Agent Wallison with regard to certain pupils in his Agency which he considers require institutional care. He tried to obtain admission for them at the Alberni School but was unable to do so and later endeavoured to place them in either the Alert Bay or Port Simpson Residential Schools. He now advises that there are no vacancies in either of the latter named schools.

There are vacancies in the St. George's Residential School in Lytton, B.C. and I would like to have your opinion regarding the placing of these children in that school from a place so far north as this Agency. I was talking to Mr. Hoey and he thinks this is something that should be allowed to stand until a new School Inspector has been appointed.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Your File 159-1-10

With reference to Mr. Phelan's letter of October 30th regarding the proposed admission of Indian children from the Babine Agency to the St. George's Indian Residential School, I may say that the suggestion originated from this office as a result of some criticism offered of the assistance extended by the Indian Agent to Joyce Brown, an orphan child of the Glen Vowell Band.

The matter was recently discussed with Rev. Hives who informs me that he has accommodation for approximately forty boys and ten girls at the school and if there are a number of children from the Babine Agency who would benefit by attending a Residential school I am of the opinion that it would be advisable to arrange for their admission to St. George's, particularly as the location of this school is no more distant from the Babine Agency than the Alberni Residential School. If there are a number of children to go to the St. George's Residential school, no doubt Mr. Mallinson can arrange for an adult Indian to escort them to Lytton.

The Secretary Indian Affairs Branch Ottawa Ontario

Enclosed are applications for admission to St. George's Indian Residential School, for the following children of the Agency.

Estelle Evelyn Wilson Age 8 Cook's Ferry Band
Freddie Washington Age 12 Lower Nicola Band
Eddie Boston Age 13 Lower Nicola Band.

G.E. Sharpe
Indian Agent.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ontario.

I wish to advise you of two regrettable incidents in connection with some of the children sent from this Agency to St. George's Indian Residential School, Lytton, B.C.

On or about December 21st, I received information from the parents of two children, namely, Elijah Turner, and Ben Woods, regarding articles lost by their respective daughters, Rita Turner, and Lulu Woods. The information I received was to the effect that these articles had been "taken", but it was found, according to the Rev. Canon Hives' reply, that the two articles belonging to Rita Turner were lost through her own carelessness. However, all articles lost at the school were found and returned to the rightful owners.

Between December 21st and December 31st, three parents, namely, Elijah Turner, Ben Woods, and Arthur Mowatt, informed me that their children were not receiving sufficient food, one of them stating that they did not receive milk, and that they were losing weight. I asked these parents to wait until I had received a reply from Canon Hives, about which subject I intended writing him. However, the day Elijah Turner informed me as above, he again visited this office and stated that he intended driving down to Lytton to take out his three children from that school, in spite of my remonstrating with him to wait until I had heard from the Principal. I therefore gave him a letter addressed to Canon Hives, which I now confess, should have been sent by mail.

All the information I received - which it was my duty to investigate - has been definitely found to be untrue, and I am writing Canon Hives, regretting the trouble that has been caused by my letters written in all innocence, and conveying my full confidence in him and in his school, in regard to the welfare of the children.
of this agency. I am also enclosing a copy of this letter to Canon Hives.

As the three Turner children and Lulu Woods have now returned home, will you kindly give me your advice as to whether these children are eligible for the Family Allowances. I may state that the Hazelton Indian Day School is still closed, having no teacher appointed.

S. Mallinson,
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, February 1, 1946.

Mr. S. Mallinson, Indian Agent,
Hazelton, Ont.

I have your letter of the 8th instant, in reference to certain complaints that you received regarding the St. George's School. It is noted that you have now ascertained that the complaints were unfounded.

I do not understand the statement made in the last paragraph of your letter, that the three Turner children and Lulu Woods have returned home. When children are placed in a residential school, discharge can only be allowed when the official approval of the Department has been given. Our file does not indicate that any approval for the discharge of these children was either requested or authorized.

I cannot understand why the Principal allowed the children to go home.

On reviewing our file I find that for some unaccountable reason no reply was made to your letter of December 3. The Department approves the admission of the children whom you mention in that letter and whose admission to the school you recommended. It is possible that you have visited the St. George's School, but if you have not done so, I believe it would be advisable for you to pay a visit to the school whenever your other duties will permit. As there are children from your agency attending the school it is important that you should have first hand information regarding its whole operation. I am certain that the Principal would appreciate a visit from you. Please let me hear further from you.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Divisi

ATTENTION:- Mr. P. Phelan.

Re. Alice Joyce Brown, 11, Protestant.

Dear Sir:

Pupil No. 0273, Edna Frank has come back to us of her own accord, seeking further training. I recommended her discharge at the end of the June quarter. I would now recommend that she be reinstated as a pupil of this school.

I would now recommend the discharge of the following pupils: No. 478, Louis Singer. His parents seem to have moved away from this part of the country. No. 491, Andrew Hance. This boy simply won't settle down to routine, and is unhappy in school, and has to be constantly watched or he runs away. I would recommend his discharge. No. 497, Alec Hance, came to us too late in life. We took him in from hospital, and built him up physically, but he did not make a good pupil. I would recommend his discharge. No. 0295, Violet Spike, has recently lost her father, and is required at home with her mother. I would recommend her discharge.

Dear Sir:

There are a number of names on our School roll of pupils who have not returned; and from what I can gather of their activities, would be just as well off the roll as discharged pupils. They are as follows:

Nos. 405, 412, 426, 436, 455, Billy Swakem, Gordon Jumbo, James Swakem, Sandy Munro, Francis Joe Thom respectively, are living and working at their home. Most of them are helping on ranches, and riding horseback most of the time; which is very much more interesting to them than being in a classroom. I would recommend their discharge.

Nos. 484, 488, 489, Lawrence Brown, Max Woods, Sam Derrick respectively, are Hazelton boys. I understand their people were not in a position to buy their fare back to school. I have written the Indian Agent about them, but I believe the Agency has recently had a change there. I would recommend their discharge. Dear Mr Phelan:

I have your letter of the 5th inst., in reference to March Quarterly Returns. Sorry I made a mistake in the adding. I was under doctor's orders to go easy at that time. In fact, he warned me I would have to give up, until I went to a Heart Specialist in Vancouver, and got his O.K. But that does not excuse my making mistakes.

In regard to Amy Edmunds. As perhaps you are aware, the Ashcroft Reserve is a poor place, and seems to be nobody's baby, from the agency standpoint. It is about sixty miles away from us, and not an easy road. I made several trips to get Amy, but she seemed to have the knack of evading me. Then the Indian Agent phoned me at the beginning of January, and said he had her in custody, or the police had, and she was sent to us at that time. Toward the end of March, I found a home for her, for she is not a good influence here in school. She was in Police Court several times during the Summer for drunkenness etc. If she is able to give a good account of herself, I would like to ask for her discharge from school.

Lily George was admitted to the Coqualeetza Hospital on Mar. 6th. But she was in the Lytton Hospital a week or two before that. I have not asked for her discharge at the present time because she has no mother, and her father is serving a life sentence for murder. If she is cured at Coqualeetza Hospital, she would have to return here.

Yours faithfully

Hazelton, B.C. June 5, 1947.

Major D.M. McKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

With reference to your correspondence with the District Inspector of Schools concerning the suggestion of the Reverend Canon C.F. Hives that fares of pupils of this Agency to St. George's School should be subsidized, I wish to express complete agreement. Even when all Day Schools are in operation, there are a great many children whose unsatisfactory home environment prejudices their proper education. If a residential School for Protestant children had been available in this area during the past school year, I venture to say that more than fifty children might have sought admittance. It does not seem fair that those who seek better education and discipline for their children should have to pay approximately $60 per capita annually in fares. I would suggest that the Department might agree to pay a child's fare to a Residential School in future, leaving it to the parents to pay the fare home for the holidays. There are other cases where the parents would be unable to afford transportation in either direction and this applies particularly in several overcrowded homes where the health and welfare of the whole family would benefit by the removal of some of the children to a Residential School.

"J.V. Boys"

I asked them about school conditions there at Hazelton, and they informed me that things had improved considerably during the last year. I then asked them if they were considering having the two children home after holidays, in order to attend the day school there, and they said a decidedly "No." That their children were well taken care of here, and they knew they were safe, and under good influence, which they were afraid of at home. But their one worry was the transportation fare. Last year, they paid for their children both ways, and they found it heavy. I think it was something like sixty dollars the round trip each.

Do you think the Department would consider paying one way? Under the present circumstances, St. George's is the only school available, and we are a long way off. They are excellent children, and worthy of all we can do for them. I would like very much to have two dozen of them, for they help our children quite a bit, and our children help them.

I would be very much obliged if you would look into this matter, and if possible, secure some financial assistance for them, in order that they may send more of their children here.

Yours faithfully,

"Ches. F. Hives"

Principal.

Dear Commissioner MacKay:

I am replying to your letter 13-11-1, relative to the three Quash girls of the Stikine agency.

During the month of November last, I received a letter from Mr. Indian agent Samson, asking me to try and find a home for these three girls during the holiday months, rather than send them back to their old home. He also added that if I would send him an account of the expenses in the matter of board, he would see that it was paid for. Last year we had just one of the girls, and I found a reliable family who were anxious to take her in, and I paid them at the rate of $15.00 per month. I was quite prepared to do the same again this year for the three.

For various reasons I would recommend that no pupils should be in this school during the two holiday months. Those who know the Fraser canyon will appreciate how like an oven this flat top building becomes when the temperature reaches 117 degrees, as it frequently does. Children become terribly disappointed at being left in school when all the others are going home. We are also anxious to have the building free of pupils, so that as much painting and repairing as possible may be done.

I have no doubt the Department will let me know if they decide that the expense of boarding these children is our responsibility.

Yours faithfully,

"Chas F. Hives"
Principal

AIR MAIL

Ottawa, August 29th, 1947.

Mr. J.V. Boys, Indian Agent,
Hazelton, B.C.

We have your letter of the 13th instant enclosing copies of letters that you have directed to the principals of the St. George's Residential School and the Alberni Residential School with reference to placing children from your agency in those institutions.

We realize that owing to unsatisfactory home conditions it is often necessary to place children in residential schools. However, if home conditions are satisfactory we prefer that the children attend the day school on the reserve.

We also know that some of our day schools have been closed owing to shortage of teachers. I particularly refer to Kitsegukla. In this connection I would point out that on August 16th we notified Indian Commissioner Mackay that we approved the appointment of Mrs. A.M. Evans as teacher of this school and, consequently, it will be in operation for the coming academic year and any children whose home conditions are satisfactory should attend this school, rather than go to a residential school.

From past experience we have found that it is a mistake to send children to a residential school located at a very great distance from their homes and to a locality where conditions are altogether different from their homes.

The question of summer holidays always arises
and it has not been our practice to pay transportation expenses for holidays for pupils whose homes are a considerable distance from the residential school they are attending.

With reference to Joyce Brown, the principal of the St. George's Residential School at Lytton had no authority to send her home unless he was assured that her parents or guardian would provide the cost of her return trip. I am writing him to this effect and no doubt he will send you the money to bring her back.

With the above in mind we are prepared to favourably consider applications for admission to residential schools for children whose home conditions are unsatisfactory and on whose reserves schools will not be operated during the coming academic year. However, as intimated above, we hope to secure teachers for all our day schools as soon as possible and this will obviate the necessity for sending several children to residential schools.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Training Division.

Ottawa, August 29th, 1947.

Dear Mr. Hives:

We have a letter from Indian Agent Boys in which he states that Joyce Brown was returned to Hazelton for the summer holidays and is now applying to the Agent for the funds to pay her return fare.

As you are aware, it has not been our practice to pay transportation costs of children in residential schools to permit them to go home for holidays if their reserves are situated a long distance from the residential school. This applies in the case of Joyce Brown.

We did not give any authority for her to go on holidays and under the circumstances it is felt that her return transportation should either have been guaranteed by the parents or guardians at the time or payment made from school funds.

No doubt you will communicate with Mr. Boys with reference to having her returned to the St. George's School.

Yours sincerely,

Philip Phelan

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. Mines & Resources, Ottawa, Ont.,

In reply to your letter of August 29th, please find enclosed applications for admission for a number of pupils to Alberni Indian Residential School and to St. Georges Indian Residential School. In connection with these applications I would refer you to my letter of August 13th and copies of letters to the Principals of these two schools explaining the family circumstances of the new applicants. In addition to these the following applications were accepted by the respective Principals:

ALBERNI INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

George Cyril Harris, Gloria Louise Harris and Vera Evelyn Harris: These are the children of Jeffrey Harris of Kispiox whose children have made good progress in school. The parents were very concerned at the time of application that no teacher had been found for the Kispiox school and for this reason these applications were submitted to the Principal of the Alberni School who agreed to take them. A teacher has recently been appointed at Kispiox.

Norma Margaret Morrison: This is the foster daughter of Moses Morrison, councillor at Kispiox, whose wife recently underwent a serious operation following chronic illness of long duration. Because the mother will not be able to care for the child permission was asked to send her to Alberni and Mr. Caldwell agreed to accept her.

Of the other children mentioned in my letter to Mr. Caldwell, Roy Phillip Wesley and Allen David Wesley were unable to go with the children from this Agency owing to sickness at the time of departure.

ST. GEORGE INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

Of the children listed in my letter to the Principal, Ralph and James Lattie were not sent, Norman Green was not physically fit and Angel Green was not acceptable to the principal. In place of these children the following were sent: Leonard Ivan Sexsmith, this boy's father is dead and his mother has, for a long time, been a patient in Hazelton Hospital. He is not receiving proper care and was therefore admitted to St. George's school. Marjorie Harris; this child has for some years been a hospital case suffering from Potts disease of the spine. Recently discharged from hospital, the doctor asked if provision could be made to have her placed in a Residential school, particularly in view of a somewhat unsatisfactory home environment.

I trust that all these applications may receive your approval for in all cases the best interests of both the children and their families are being served by sending them away to school.

J.V. Boys
Indian Agent.

Pupils Nos. 0383, 0281, 0298, 0330, 0331, 0418, 0414, 0296, 0345, Annie Edwards, Mary J. Charlie, Maggie Dick, Matilda Drynock, Gloria Drynock, Alice Harry, Evelyn Drynock, Alana Dick, Doreen Charlie, respectively, belong to the class of people, whose parents make many demands and many complaints. We have had to almost beg them to send their children, and they, on their part have considered they were doing us a tremendous favour by allowing their children to come. Their children have not yet returned to school. Others have taken their place. I feel the school will not only be better off...
without them, but a slight feeling of independence on our part is good tonic for the school. We have 150 pupils in residence at the moment. Some have to sleep on the floor on matresses, but that will be remedied as soon as the new promised beds arrive. I would recommend that they be allowed to stay home for the time being.

Pupils Nos. 0378, 0411, 0311, 423 are pupils whose health is a menace to other pupils, and whose parents are not willing for them to be sent to the hospital. I would recommend their discharge from our school. They are Mabel Phillips, Dillys Phillips, Dora Hance, Francis Lachelle respectively.

Dear Sir:

There are several explanations required to be made in connection with the quarterly returns.

Pupil No. 0259 Dorothy Swartz has been away from school for over a year. While in school we found her to be a very satisfactory pupil, and she passed her eighth grade while here. At that time there was no Continuation school in Lytton. There is now, and our pupils are invited to attend as they reach the educational standing. Dorothy Swartz wished to attend, but she would be greatly handicapped if she remained home; so after talking the matter over with Mr. Indian Agent Strang, I took her in. I don't think we made any mistake, and would recommend that she be recognised by the Department as a Grant earning High School pupil. I have also left Pupil No. 432 Hector McIntyre on the school roll, though he is attending High School, and living at home.

Pupil No. 452 Archie Blankinship was allowed to stay home at the commencement of term, with the understanding that he attend the Public School in Merritt. I recently received a letter from the Merritt Indian Agent asking me to take him back, as they could do nothing with him. I have therefore admitted him, and would recommend that he continue as before on the roll. His brother, Adam Blankinship 497 has just been under tonsil operation, and I expect he will have to return to us when he is well.

I would also recommend the Discharge of Pupils Nos. 0304, 0307, Hazel Munro, Helen Machelle. These two girls are required at their respective homes to help mothers with large families.

Dear Sir:

I am writing in reference to transportation of pupils from the Prince Rupert district to St. George's School, Lytton. Last term we had thirty-one pupils from that district; and their transportation expenses, amounting to over four hundred dollars, was shared by the parents and St. George's School.

I am most anxious to have these pupils return to us again at the beginning of the Fall term; and from letters received from parents, pupils and the Indian Agent, it would appear that they are anxious for the pupils to return. Moreover, I am of the opinion that, on account of the difference in language, our Lytton Indian pupils, along with those from the Coast, learn to talk better English, because English must be their common form of speech.

Had we not taken in these children, it is not likely that they would have attended any school last year, and they are at the age when it is very necessary that they should receive an education and training. It is therefore the responsibility of the Department that they should have access to either a day school or a residential school.

I would, therefore, respectfully ask that the Department assume the cost of transportation one way; and as the return home, at the commencement of holidays was shared by parents and school, so the transportation expenses from home to school again, under the circumstances referred to above, be assumed by the Department.

Yours faithfully,

Dear Canon Hives:

We have your letter of the 6th instant regarding the pupils from the Prince Rupert district who attended St. George's Residential School last year.

We note that you suggest that we provide $400. for their transportation back to the school. We feel that this matter should have been brought to our attention before the children left for holidays.

In residential schools in Eastern Canada, it is the general practice to retain at the school during the summer holidays those children whose home reserve is a considerable distance from the school concerned.

These children only went to the school last year and in any case, we would not consider allowing a heavy expenditure for transportation after such a short sojourn in a residential school.

Yours sincerely,

Bernard F. Neary
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Colonel Neary:

In reply to your letter 165-0-10, received today, and relative to transportation expenses of Prince Rupert children from home to school.

You will, no doubt, recall my speaking to you about this matter in your office during my visit there in May. You say, in your letter, that children, who are so far distant from home, should remain in school during the holiday months. I wonder if you know, or realize the kind of a place the Frazer Canyon is during those months. Quite frequently the temperature rises to 110 degrees, and our building becomes an oven unbearable to sleep in, or have children living in. We have absolutely nothing in the way of a swimming pool, or place where boys or girls can find access to bathing beaches. And the Fraser river, which is an attraction to any boy in the hot weather is treacherous and unsafe. Moreover, we are trying in every way possible, to stimulate the family and social life of these people. You cannot do that if you are going to deprive them of personal social intercourse by keeping them apart for years.

The matter, as I see it is this: If the pupils from Prince Rupert, who have no access to educational facilities near to their own homes, come to St. George's School, the school should not be expected to meet their transportation expenses. The parents are willing to pay one way. Either they must pay both ways, or we must receive financial assistance from the Department in returning them to school after holidays. I do not think this school can finance this matter out of the grant earnings.

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Principal.

Superintendent of Education,

Dear Sir:

Referring to the September Quarterly Returns, there are several matters I would comment on.

Nearly all pupils, shown in the returns, were in residence within four days of the 1st of September. Other years they have come dribbling in, some as late as December. Those who were late this year found their room filled up with new comers, and had to return home. I am sorry this has happened, for I am afraid they will not receive the proper care they should this winter, and they will miss their classroom education. Last year, we had similar conditions. One family of three girls did not arrive until late, and they had to return home for lack of accommodation here. They were amongst the first to be on hand this year. Next year I expect there will be few if any tardy ones.

During the month of August I wrote you, asking for four hundred dollars for the purpose of transportation of pupils from Prince Rupert to our school. You very kindly sanctioned that amount. All pupils came from Prince Rupert to our school with no expense to school or Department. In my experience, that is one of the biggest things for good that has happened, and shows they are beginning to appreciate what we are doing for them.

There are several pupils whose discharge from our school I would recommend: No. 407 Wesley Munro, 16 yrs' old, required on his father's farm. 431 Dennis Seymour kept at home for the same purpose. 460 Alonzo Williams home for the same purpose. 464 Elmer Casimir, whose guardian Grandmother is a Roman Catholic, stayed away until our school was filled up, and is now attending St. Mary's School at Mission. I would recommend that he be admitted to that school. Adam Blankinship, 497, Clifford Kirkpatrick, 494, Florence and Gloria Kirkpatrick, 0407, 0435 are all attending day school near their respective homes. 514, 518, Robert Stevens & Fred Lincoln respectively did not return. 0275, 0279, 0312, 0317
Angeline Edmunds, Thelma Raphael, Ruth Samson, Loretta Smith respectively, are at home with their parents.

Priscilla Isaac, who was attending High School last year secured a fairly good situation during the holidays, and is staying with it.

I would recommend that the above pupils be discharged from our school.

The other pupils who are now absent owing to lack of accommodation when they came late, will most likely be on hand in good time next term. In this respect I may say, we shall not have accommodation for all who wish to be admitted. Our classrooms at present are greatly overcrowded, owing to more of our pupils attending full time in the classrooms. The classroom accommodation was originally intended for the half day system. If we are to meet the demands of the full day in classroom, we must have much larger accommodation. This is a matter which requires careful and immediate attention.

Yours faithfully,

May I refer you to the accompanying quarterly returns, to explain the uncertain attendance in the classrooms. Some pupils returned from holidays with measles. We isolated these as soon as we possibly could, but not before they had broadcasted the germs amongst the other pupils. I am happy to say that we have no serious cases.

More than one hundred and fifty pupils returned before the first day of September, and the balance within two days after. This is an entirely different state of affairs from what it was seven or eight years ago. At that time I almost had to go on my knees begging parents to send their children to school, and the school had been in the habit of chasing around after them. This year, they came of their own accord without any effort on our part. For over five years we have had no runaway children from school, and during that time I have given no corporal punishments. If we took in all the children whose parents are asking for their admission we would be greatly overcrowded. None have come in from Hazelton, although there are two dozen at that agency waiting for word from me to take them in. I understand they have no teacher at the day school there.

You will note that we have sixteen pupils on this roll with High School standing. Three of these have been accepted to take their training in the School of Nursing Aides in Calgary, and have to report there on the morning of Oct. 24th. We shall then have thirteen attending High School. Three of these are attending from their homes, and which are in close proximity to the school. Most of these pupils are most anxious to take courses in the Industrial Arts, Motor Mechanics, Home economics etc. The school at Lytton gives only those subjects that would prepare pupils for University. My opinion is that there is a very small percentage of pupils normally fit to take a University course, and the large percentage fall by the way. But if and when they manage to get through, they have great difficulty competing for a livelihood in the professional world.

We must have either a High School at Lytton teaching the Industrial Arts etc., or our pupils should go to some place where is situated a Technical High School, such as the one in Sault Ste. Marie. I anticipate having seven or eight more pupils from Grade VIII next year, seeking advanced education. This is a serious matter; for one thing, by these pupils continuing here, deprives little Indian children from entering our school. I am definitely of the opinion that if children are to enter the residential school,
Last evening, I attended a meeting of the Board of Trade, recently organized in Lytton. The matter of the need of a modern High School building came up for discussion, and it was generally agreed that a school with combined instruction in Industrial Arts etc., would best meet the needs of the community. The present building is the abandoned school house, which is inconvenient, uncomfortable, and over-crowded. The reason I am interested in this matter is because St. George's School would, in the future, provide a large percentage of High School pupils. A committee was appointed, of which I am one, to investigate the matter from all angles, and to report at the next meeting. I am convinced that it is a situation which will have to be met, and dealt with properly. I am also convinced that nothing will be done unless Indian Affairs gives a substantial financial assistance to this important matter. If such a building did materialize, then we should need a hostel for St. George's School to accommodate thirty High School pupils, with quarters for a married couple, who would care for them, and give assistance in their home work.

This matter is not a small venture, but an important one, and will have to be faced and dealt with accordingly. May I report to you again on this matter?

Dear Major Davey:

This should have been written last night, as I promised to do, but on my arrival home, I found things on the farm pretty much at a standstill, for my Farm Manager was ill in bed, and the insilage cutting at rest, and the potatoes not in. So I have been very busy at these things, and making them safe before Winter comes on.

With reference to the matter of making accommodation for more pupils, I have gone into this, and have a recommendation to make to you. The two top rooms of the main, or centre part of the building, were originally intended for dormitories, but have never been used as such. One has been used as a girls' sewing and mending room; and the other as a boys' sewing and mending room. Part of the boys' dormitory was taken off and used as a spinning and weaving room, and is now occupied by looms which are never used. I am enclosing plans of the rooms, as they are now, and as I would recommend they should be.

If these rooms are used as dormitories, some accommodation will have to be found for the sewing and mending department, which is a very important one in this school; for all girls' clothing is made, and much mending is required with two hundred girls and boys. We can manage this with the girls, as we have a room on the ground floor, which can be used for that purpose. It is 23'x16' and would require proper and convenient furniture in the way of shelves, cupboards and lockers. By the second plan, which is a recommendation, you will notice that I would advise taking half the other room on the top floor for a boys' sewing and mending room. This also would have to be properly furnished with shelves, cupboards and lockers. When this building was handed over for occupation after it was built, no provision was made in the matter of shelves, lockers and cupboards. In the rooms which now accommodate the sewing and mending, we have old cupboards taken out of the old school, and very roughly made shelves.

You will also note that a certain amount of partition would have to be built, and one wall pulled out. But this would not entail very much work or expense. We here can do all the wood work, if we have the proper lumber for
making shelves, cupboards and lockers. We can put up the studding and lath for the partitions, but would require a plasterer to do the finishing.

By estimation of the cost of this would be twelve hundred dollars.

As you are aware, our dormitories at present are over-crowded. With the opening up of the top centre dormitories, we could take in a total of 215 pupils. I would put the smallest of the girls and boys in the two dormitories. You will note there is a toilet of each dorm.

If we are to increase our pupilage, we would require more accommodation for classroom work. And if we had a classroom block, I would recommend that we allow all children living within the three mile limit of the school, to live at home and attend school here. That would mean a school bus service, and we would have to provide mid-day meal for the ones who would come by bus. At present we could count on, at least, twenty four pupils who could live at home, and attend school by bus service.

This is a matter worthy of consideration, and one which might work out alright. The thing is, we, at St. George's School must have more accommodation or another school similar to this should be built in the north to relieve us of the northern children.

Yours faithfully,

I wish to advise that I am unable to obtain any satisfaction regarding pupils from this Agency attending St. George's Indian Residential School at Lytton, who should have returned to that school early this month.

On the 27th August I received a telegram from the Principal as follows - "PLEASE DO NOT LET CHILDREN RETURN UNTIL YOU HEAR FROM ME WILL WRITE YOU AFTER END OF MONTH. CHAS S HIVES, PRINCIPAL". We accordingly informed parents to this effect and awaited Canon Hive's letter.

In the early part of September I was obliged to absent myself from the Agency Office in order to take Dr. Galbraith's X-ray unit to Fort Babine but on my return I wrote Canon Hives on 9th September informing him that I had not received the promised letter and asking for the reason for the delay as to when these children should leave. I have received no reply.

I now learn that Mr. Anfield's children were not subject to the same request from Canon Hives and returned to school early in September.

Among the children was one Norma Wale, whose home environment was such that I had asked Canon Hives before during the summer holidays of 1948 and again this year, that he keep the child at Lytton throughout the holidays. I learn today that without any notification to this Office whatsoever, Norma was discharged from St. George's school on 14th August 1949 and is now living with a couple in Prince Rupert who are living common law.

This high handed treatment of pupils of this Agency by Canon Hives is just not good enough and I would ask that an immediate investigation be made. At least I should be informed what is his grievance, if any.
It is true that in the past year or two since my arrival in this Agency we have been forwarding children whose home environment demanded that some provision be made for them in a residential school.
