I attach herewith a file of correspondence between this office and the principal of the above mentioned school. Also attached are copies of letters from Mr. Superintendent Boys to this office and to the Reverend Principal, which gave rise to our correspondence with Canon Hives. It will be noted that Mr. Boys lists in his letter of Sept. 30th the names of nine pupils attending the St. George's Residential School in the past year. Of this number it is understood that two have returned to the school. The others were not returned at the beginning of the school term, at the specific request of Canon Hives in his telegram of August 27th to Mr. Boys. Mr. Boys rightfully assumed that this request of the principal was merely for a delay in sending the pupils down. On our receipt of Mr. Boys' letter dated Sept. 30th Inspector Davey wrote to Canon Hives requesting that he visit this office. Canon Hives visited Inspector Davey on October 12th and I also had an opportunity of speaking to him. Both Inspector Davey and myself made it quite clear to the Principal that first priority on admissions to his school should be given to necessitous cases. It was also made clear to him that the principal of the school did not have the right of discharging pupils without first consulting the Agent concerned. Immediately following receipt of Canon Hives' letter of October 18th, Inspector Davey called him by telephone and pointed out that it was absolutely essential that the pupils who should not have been discharged from his school be returned immediately and that accommodation should be
made either through the discharge of pupils not requiring institutional care or through the use of dormitory accommodation presently occupied by the sewing classes. These suggestions were apparently not acceptable. Canon Hives gives as his reasons: (a) The school cannot afford the cost of transporting the children from Hazelton to Lytton. (b) The sewing room is absolutely essential to the successful operation of the school. You will note from the attached diagram prepared by the principal that the sewing classes occupy a space 34 x 36, which in the opinion of this office, is out of all proportion to the school's requirements. Apparently the main objection of the principal is on the grounds of cost. It was pointed out to him that two years ago a grant of $400.00 was made by the Department for transporting pupils, which amount he returned to the Department and has not requested further assistance.

The attitude of the principal is clearly indicated in one specific case mentioned by Mr. Boys in which a girl whose home environment was such that he had requested the principal to keep the child during the summer holidays was released from the school without any notification to the Superintendent. The girl is now living in Prince Rupert with a couple who are living in common-law.

In spite of Inspector Davey's conversation with Canon Hives he still has no assurance from the Reverend Principal that these very necessitous cases formerly enrolled at the residential school will be re-admitted.

Our latest action is indicated in the attached copy of Inspector Davey's letter to the Principal dated October 19th. I shall report later as to whether or not these instructions have been carried out. I am informing you fully at this time in anticipation of the principal referring the matter direct to the Department.

W.S. Arneil,

Dear Mr. Helen:

I have a matter on my mind which is causing me some concern or worry. It is in regard to increased pupilage. You are aware of the circumstances surrounding St. George's, and the difficulties arising from prejudice which seemed to be in the minds of the Indian parents against this school eight years ago. You remember how difficult it was to persuade parents to send in the children, and in consequence the small grant allowance we received.

There were lots of children around, but the parents didn't want to send them here. That condition has changed, I think, perhaps, one of the factors which brought about the change was the admitting of the Prince Rupert area children. After they began to come in, and find satisfactory conditions here, then the parents in this district began to take up so that now our dormitories are overcrowded, and there is quite a waiting list.

Mr. Indian Superintendent Amfield asked me how many could be taken again from his district, and I told him the same number as last year. These, along with some from our vicinity, totalling 150, arrived here two days before the term officially started. The balance of two hundred arrived two days after. I was therefore unable to bring in all the Hazelton children, who were here last year. This has brought about rather an unpleasant feeling in the mind of the Indian Superintendent at Hazelton and Inspector Davy. I did not realize that our own people could rush their children in so quickly, and, other years, the one thing that the pupils lived for was their discharge from school. This year, several returned, when I hardly expected, with the hope that they may attend the Junior High School next year.

We could take in more pupils if the two top dormitories in the centre part of the building were opened up for that purpose. They have never yet been used as such, but have been used as sewing rooms. No other provision has ever been made for sewing rooms. We could accommodate sewing rooms in other similar rooms if they were fitted up properly. But they would require proper shelves, cupboards and lockers. We can do the work as a Manual Training project, but we would
require the material, lumber and hardware. We would also require twenty small beds, mattresses and bedding.

We have not used very much of the sanctioned amount for repairs allotted for our school. I estimate that $1,500.00 would be required to do the necessary work in fitting up sewing rooms and purchasing beds etc.

I believe this matter has been placed before you by Commissioner Arnold. I would be very much obliged if you would consider this as favourably and as soon as possible.

I went up to Hazelton two weeks ago, just to compare conditions there with those of our Indians here. The Indians at Hazelton live in places as compared with our poor little shacks. And they make a great deal more money there than do our Indians. They also have three schools, which are within a quarter of a mile of any of the children. But they also have some very poor family conditions. Broken homes through drink etc. I have promised to take back six of the children, who are desperately in need of institutional care, just as soon as we have accommodation for them.

Yours faithfully,

Discharges from Residential School.

During the quarter under review there were two children discharged from Lejac, one from Lytton Residential and two from Grouard Mission, Alta.,

Dear Major Davey:

I am making the necessary arrangements for the Summer Holiday transportation of the Prince Rupert area pupils from Lytton to Prince Rupert. This is quite an expensive item, as there are twenty-eight pupils, and I feel it is a bit too much to expect the parents to bear all the expense. The fare from Lytton to Prince Rupert by rail and boat with escort amounts to $772.20. And with incidentals in the way of meals in Vancouver, while awaiting all day to board the boat at night, would bring the total to $800.00. While I feel that the parents should be responsible for a part of this; yet in view of the fact that these children must come to us until such time as facilities are available for them near home, or miss their education and training entirely; and that many are from poor homes, I feel justified in asking the Department for half the amount, or four hundred dollars.

The matter of allowing them to stay here during the holidays should not be considered. These children are Coast children. To a large extent they are living for their Summer holidays, when they will be home; no matter what their home conditions are, and they will see and smell the sea again.

I would, therefore, be very much obliged if you would place this matter before authority, and recommend that we receive the amount of $400.00 toward the cost of transportation of pupils from St. George's School at Lytton to Prince Rupert. I would then ask the Prince Rupert Superintendent to take a hand in asking the parents to do their part in paying the balance.

Yours faithfully,

(Sgd.) Chas. F. Hives,
Principal.

Major R.F. Davey,
Inspector of Indian Schools,
Vancouver, B.C.

Re: St. George's Indian Residential School - Lytton, B.C.

Attached please find a copy of a letter received from Canon Hives, Principal of the above named school, requesting an allowance in the amount of $400.00 to assist in the matter of transportation costs for children returning home to the Prince Rupert area for the summer holidays. The distance involved is in the neighborhood of 1000 miles, but the St. George's School is not alone in this respect as the same conditions prevail in the case of the Edmonton, Alberni, and to a lesser extent, Alert Bay Schools. I believe that in the majority of cases the parents can very well pay the cost of transportation and should be made to assume some responsibility with regard to the education of their children.

There are undoubtedly some children from this area who should not be discharged from the care of the Residential School at all. However, because I feel that a consistent policy should be enforced and in view of the fact that several schools in British Columbia receive assistance, particularly the St. Mary's Residential School at Mission, where the distances from which the pupils are transported are a fraction of those in the case of the schools mentioned above, I am referring this matter to the Department for a decision.

My recommendation in this matter is that no assistance be granted to any school in the matter of children returning home for holidays.

W. S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
